column10: This game eats my storage with every save without any reason
:V

Is it a good game? Yes. but...

My biggest concern is how the camera angles are so bad when I'm near a terrain or a building. Even if I press the "lock on" key I still can't see the enemy. Sure, I can still continue the combo without seeing my character but it sucks when I'm up against enemies on their "burst mode" (ex. crocodile, blackbeard, ace) as they keep interrupting combos and I can't see anything other than walls covering the screen and my HP depleting.

And what is up with the delay in announcing that I beat an enemy? They're dead but the dialogue has to continue? Like I beat Kaido but he still talking and not dropping food or sword or shield until it's done? The mission ended a minute ago but I have to wait until Kaido (and his spirit?) ends his dialogue while I watch Luffy idling or running and all the minions crying? Tf

I tried getting used to it but it's hella annoying in the New World log. If not for the remaining 3 achievements (technically 2) I would have dipped this game.

Guys, I just finished playing One Piece: Pirate Warriors 4, and let me tell you, it's seriously addictive! First off, the gameplay is incredible! Each character has these amazing moves that make battles so intense. And the graphics? They're absolutely stunning, making me feel like I'm truly immersed in the world of One Piece!

What I love most about this game is how faithfully it adapts the story from the manga and anime. Every character and iconic moment from One Piece is here, and I love being able to relive their adventures.

Oh, and let's not forget about the content! There's a story mode that's so much fun to play through, plus side missions that keep you coming back for more. So, whether you're a die-hard One Piece fan or just looking to give it a try, I highly recommend checking out this game. You won't regret it!

As someone who only started watching One Piece in the middle of November of last year (now in the middle of Marineford as I write this) I was curious about what I was in store for since I wasn't familiar with the "Musou" genre of games but I can say that for my first outing it's been a blast all throughout. It never gets old to just barrel through a crowd of people sending them flying in all different directions just to throw some quick combos and specials leveling props and buildings in a matter of seconds, you truly feel like an unstoppable force during these skirmishes and the simplicity of the controls makes it very easy to just pickup and play however I did end up feeling like a certain "Mosshead" because THESE MAPS TURN ME AROUND TOO DAMN MUCH! But that's ok, at least it makes playing Zoro feel more genuine.

Title: One Piece: Pirate Warriors 4 

Introduction:
One Piece: Pirate Warriors 4, developed by Omega Force and published by Bandai Namco Entertainment, is the latest installment in the action-packed One Piece Warrior series. Set in the vast and vibrant world of Eiichiro Oda's popular manga and anime series, this game offers fans an immersive experience filled with intense battles, iconic characters, and a compelling storyline.

Graphics and Visuals:
Visually, One Piece: Pirate Warriors 4 is a treat for fans and newcomers alike. The cel-shaded art style perfectly captures the essence of the anime, bringing beloved characters to life with vibrant colors and fluid animations. The attention to detail in character design and the dynamic environments contribute to an engaging and visually appealing gaming experience.

Gameplay:
The core gameplay of Pirate Warriors 4 remains faithful to its hack-and-slash roots, offering players a fast-paced and exhilarating combat system. Players can choose from a vast roster of characters, each with unique abilities and signature moves. The game introduces the "Musou" action style, allowing players to unleash devastating combo attacks on hordes of enemies. The inclusion of cooperative play adds an extra layer of enjoyment, letting players team up to tackle challenging missions together.

Storyline:
The game follows the One Piece storyline, taking players through major arcs of the manga. While the narrative may not offer new content for those already familiar with the series, it serves as an excellent introduction for newcomers. The engaging cutscenes and character interactions contribute to an immersive storytelling experience, capturing the essence of the beloved source material.

Character Roster and Progression:
One Piece: Pirate Warriors 4 boasts an extensive roster of playable characters, including fan favorites like Luffy, Zoro, and Nami. Each character has a unique playstyle and special moves, providing variety and replay value. The progression system allows players to upgrade their characters, unlocking new abilities and enhancing their combat prowess. This adds a strategic element to the gameplay, encouraging players to experiment with different characters and playstyles.

Music and Sound:
The game's soundtrack complements the high-energy gameplay, featuring iconic tunes from the anime series. The voice acting, available in both English and Japanese, adds authenticity to the characters, making it an enjoyable experience for fans who prefer the original voice cast.

Conclusion:
One Piece: Pirate Warriors 4 successfully combines the beloved world of One Piece with the thrilling gameplay of the Warriors series. With its stunning visuals, diverse character roster, and engaging combat system, it offers an enjoyable experience for both fans of the franchise and action game enthusiasts. Whether you're a Straw Hat Pirate veteran or a newcomer setting sail for the first time, this game promises an exciting and swashbuckling adventure in the world of One Piece.

I've always been kind of a sucker for musou games and always enjoy them. This one is just the same as the others but I do like the additions it adds. Next to this, you can set specials/skills to each character giving a ton of variety to builds. However, it does have a ton of characters but most are utter trash sadly. It's usually the Power characters that you'll be playing the most if you want to tackle the tougher missions. Also most of the DLC characters break this game. Like a LOT. They are crazy powerful. (Recent one being Film RED Shanks is crazy OP).

Play this if your a fan of the series. If you have an interest in the series, don't. Read the manga and then jump in if you're interested. The story jumps right in the middle of a story arc a hundred chapters in the story. And it skips a TON and glosses over a ton of little details. Granted I'm not surprised since it's the overall story is so long but don't come in thinking it'll tell you everything. Overall, fun game with a few issues.

One word,
 Perfection.

Enjoying it so far, the game handles itself fairly well on the Steam Deck. I might have to go through settings to troubleshoot the controls, because using an external keyboard with my deck seems to make whatever character I'm playing as run in whatever direction they're facing for no obvious reason, making it impossible to navigate stages properly. I enjoy the graphics, but sometimes the cutscenes won't load until part way through them, showing a TV off-air type screen until it loads, even as the subtitles show up. The combat is fluid and performs well, and the steam deck controls handle well.

This isn't wildly different from the handful of other musou games I've played so far, but the characters and attacks feel different enough from each other to keep things interesting. It is definitely worth getting, though I'd personally wait for a sale.

If you're here, you're probably also a One Piece fan, and if that's the case you know enough to fill in the little gaps in the story, so you'll enjoy this-- that said if you haven't read/watched it, I wouldn't recommend this as an introduction to the narrative. This game does the best it can at condensing entire arcs to a few levels, but it inevitably has to cut parts for time. Some plot points are left as 1-2 sentence summaries, which is fine for someone who understands what's going on before but could be confusing to someone who's completely new. For example one of the more emotional parts of Water 7 (arc, not saga for existing fans, it's the duel and what leads up to it) definitely doesn't have the gravity it does in the full story. Considering it would take more than three weeks straight to watch the anime, it's not really possible for a game to go into that much depth, especially at the steal of the price it costs on sale!

Musou games are not for everyone, if you are unsure, i recommend doing some research to determine if this is the kind of game that you would be into. i do enjoy Musou games, but have only played a few others; Hyrule Warriors, Fire Emblem Warriors, and Persona 5 Strikers. This is easily the best I have played. One Piece characters are absolute powerhouses and they fit a game like this very well. It is super satisfying whacking the hell out of hordes of enemies with the various creative abilities of One Piece characters. I turn on Wendigoon videos and just mindlessly smash enemies and objectives as I listen. very fun. However, if you have not seen One Piece, i would not recommend the campaign. Cramming 100 volumes into a 10 hour story mode leaves a lot to be desired. I understand that no game could ever tell such a vast story adequately, but just wanted to mention that this can not be a substitute for the manga/show.

A middle of the road musou game. I've played worse, but a lot better too. There's a lot of cool stuff here, but there's also a lot of annoyances and tedium too. 

Positives

1. This game is frequently on sale for dirt cheap. If you want to try this game, for the love of god wait for a sale. It is almost always less than $10 dollars for the basic edition, which more than justifies it's asking price. 

2. The cast of playable characters is extremely varied and well put together. A lot of musou games cut corners by having lots of clone characters or a shared weapon system for the cast. While there are a handful of sort-of-clones here, the overwhelming majority of characters all have unique basic and special attacks that often make them play completely differently from anyone else. While this does result in the roster being very unbalanced, with some characters being absurdly more powerful than others, almost all the characters are at least interesting to play.

3. The game scales well for a variety of machines. This developer is notorious for poor optimization on PC, but I was able to get satisfactory performance and visuals on both desktop and the ROG Ally with everything still looking great. I had a little initial trouble getting my xbox controller to work, but this was easily sorted in the steam settings. Overall this game looks great and runs at 60 fps even on middle of the road machines. 

4. The combat is flashy and impactful. The basic musou weak-strong attack combo system has been further expanded to include air combos and a customizable palette of special moves that can all be linked together fluidly. As an added bonus, environmental destruction is a prominent feature here, with entire buildings crumbling to rubble form your errant attacks. These features all ramp up the power fantasy aspect of these games to new levels, making you feel like an unstoppable juggernaut who can reduce entire cities to dust. 

Negatives

1. The story presentation is atrocious. Of course this was going to be a cliff notes summary of the One Piece saga at best, I expected that, but what really surprised me was how slapped together the story segments actually feel. Still images, pre-rendered scenes, and footage that seems to be lifted straight from previous games are often mashed together in overly lengthy lore-dump sequence. It just feels like a lot of corners were cut here, and the most laughable example was the refusal to give Iceburg an in-game character model for the Water 7 sequences. All of his dialogue just comes from somewhere off-screen while the characters stand around staring at nothing. It's bizarre and unintentionally hilarious at the same time. Also, once again, there is no English voice acting in this game. For most Japanese games this isn't a problem, but it is almost impossible to follow the dialogue for half a dozen characters quickly barking orders at you in the middle of combat.

2. Named characters are very annoying to fight. By default all enemy officers have a super-armor meter you have to first deplete in order for them to stagger and take increased damage. The problem is that as soon as you do this, without fail, most named characters will activate their full-burst ability, buffing their attack and allowing them to repeatedly ragdoll your character. A few of the characters, such as Crocodile and Kizaru, are also invincible while in this state and will force you to deplete their super-armor a second time to stop it, all while they constantly blast you away with massive AOE attacks. The game overall isn't particularly difficult, but for me the fun fell off a cliff every time I had to deal with one of these assholes. 

3. Progression is pretty mediocre. You don't gain experience or level up in this game, but instead have to spend collectible coins and money to purchase raw stat boosts and abilities for each character. This system was fine overall, but I was a bit disappointed that the power ceiling felt relatively low for a Musou game. Once you're 10 hours in or so it doesn't take much effort to max out a character, and once you've filled out their ability map that's pretty much it. A dlc was recently rolled out that introduced a new progression system where you collect and spend souls for infinitesimally small stat boosts, but the currency for this is an extremely rare drop unless you own a particular dlc pack that lets you earn them more easily. Considering that a lot of other Musou games let you become ridiculously overpowered with levels in the hundreds, late game progression here just felt tame and underwhelming in comparison. 

Overall, pretty cool game, get it on sale if you are a musou or One Piece fan.

"I'm Gonna Be King Of The Pirates!"

[b]Alright, fellow gamers, it's time to set sail into the world of ONE PIECE: PIRATE WARRIORS 4, and let me tell you, it's a thrill ride packed with anime awesomeness.[/b]
[list]
[*][b]Anime Adventure: If you've been on the anime bandwagon, this game's like diving into the vibrant world of ONE PIECE. It's a celebration of epic battles and friendship, and it nails that anime vibe.[/b]

[*][b]Epic Brawler: PIRATE WARRIORS 4 doesn't hold back on the action. It's a button-mashing, combo-hitting frenzy that'll make you feel like a powerhouse. Each character's moves pack a punch, and the battles are as explosive as a Gear Fourth punch![/b]

[*][b]Visual Delight: The game's visuals capture that anime flair perfectly. It's like stepping into a living, breathing manga, with vibrant colors and smooth animations that make the action pop.[/b]

[*][b]Variety in Characters: From Luffy's rubbery antics to Zoro's swordplay, the game's got a treasure trove of characters to choose from. Each character feels unique, with their own fighting style and special moves.[/b]

[*][b]Adventure Galore: PIRATE WARRIORS 4 is like setting sail on an adventure. The story mode lets you relive iconic moments from the anime while throwing in some new twists and turns.[/b]

[*][b]Fan-Service Feast: If you're a die-hard ONE PIECE fan, this game's your treasure trove. It's like getting served a platter of fan-favorite arcs and characters to feast on.[/b]

[*][b]Co-op Shenanigans: Grab your crewmates and set sail together! The game offers co-op play, letting you and your mates unleash havoc as your favorite characters.[/b]

[*][b]Endless Replayability: With loads of missions, challenges, and collectibles, PIRATE WARRIORS 4 offers endless replay value. It's like a never-ending voyage, always offering something new to discover.[/b]
[/list]
[b]In a nutshell, ONE PIECE: PIRATE WARRIORS 4 is a must-play for any ONE PIECE fan or anyone who craves action-packed gameplay with an anime twist. It's a love letter to the series, blending epic battles, vibrant visuals, and an adventure that'll keep you hooked like a devil fruit. So hoist the sails, gather your crew, and embark on this wild, swashbuckling journey![/b]

So One Piece:Pirate Warriors 4 isn't the worst game ever, but it's not as good as its predecessor in a lot of ways. At its root it's still a Warriors title, which means you can have mindless fun bashing millions of enemies around, and in this series do it as popular one piece characters.

That said, the game suffers from what feels like rushed dev time. There's not a lot of polish and there IS a lot of DLC. There are fewer playable characters, fewer costumes, the maps feel less varied, everything feels like a step down from OPPW3 and considering this game's price and the amount of DLC you're better off going back and just playing 3 instead.

Most annoying, is that the story campaign is both not canon(because it came out before the end of the Wano arc of the manga), you also cannot do it completely co-op until you've beaten the campaign once.

Excellent Musou title!
It might take a little while to get used to the new, fast and unapologetic (sometimes confusing) gameplay if you're immediately coming after playing Pirate Warriors 3, but once you do, you'll really appreciate the changes.
What I like about this, is that it adds a different twist to the almost perfect Pirate Warriors 3 formula, so both 3 and 4 are highly valued for different things.

If I had to put it simply, I would rank them like this:

- Warriors 3: Slower gameplay and flashy team moves. 

- Warriors 4: Improved graphics, faster gameplay, no special team moves but more exciting, breakable buildings and bigger scale (giant enemies).

All in all, this is an excellent game, maybe the best One Piece game so far.

Enjoy!

This is a standard Musou game. If you like the genre and like One Piece, you're *most likely* to enjoy it as well. 
 
HOWEVER, one thing that I do think is straight wrong with it are the achievements. There is no incentive at all for you to complete all the "Treasure Log", or the extra logs that are DLC exclusive. It's funny and all, but only until so far, and to do the same mission over and over again (sometimes with a different character) only to have achievement is somewhat nonsensical to me.

At last, not having all the playable character from previous games in the series is also nonsensical to me. I wish they would have given us all the chapters from the anime (skypea, etc) and more playable characters as well.

[h1]Summary:[/h1]
A slow burn at the beginning, but after the story play through is complete, the game opens up with multiple tiers of difficulty, huge level capacity, a massive roster, and some significant increases to functional replay-ability. The transition away from Dynasty's weapon system to the abilities that exist in the progression of the show is a nice switch, especially paired with the in game maps for skill and level progression.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
- Easy to Learn, Hard to Master.
- Music is consistent with the themes, works well.
- Game play is smooth, and consistently fun.
- Character range is massive, extremely diverse cast of skills and play styles
- Giant characters are ridiculous to play as, and fun to fight

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- Online matchmaking is poorly implemented
- No ability to check status unless you start a match
- Very little guidance on unlocking skills for later characters.

[h1]Overall:[/h1]
Its the best parts of dynasty warriors packaged in the absolutely insane world of One Piece. It's fun, easy to pickup, and enjoyable to play. Get it on Sale.

[h2]Score: 8/10[/h2]

Massive One Piece fan, and a big fan of both Pirate Warriors - and Warriors games in general. This game has a lot going for it, but just as much working against it. I haven't played it a lot on Steam, but have Platinumed them all on Playstation.

Pros: Nice graphics, destructible environments, decent roster, great new additions to the roster, jumping (?), Nami., great core gameplay as always, online is pretty fun, Gear 4th

Cons: Lack of costumes, a LOT of cut story content/maps, plenty of classic characters cut from the roster this time around.

This game tries to do a lot of new things with the Warriors formula - and I can appreciate the vision, but the execution is rather lacking. The jumping and addition of "sky" combat seems great, until you realize that it interferes with a lot of character's movesets and I cannot stress enough that not all air combos were created equal. Unless you're playing a Sky type or Luffy, you're shit outta luck. I'm not a fan of the added dash/stamina system either. The new skill select is okay, I can see why people may not like it as it does interfere with established movesets once again. Personally I'd go with PW3 for the definitive "Pirate Warriors" experience.

Very Good for a One Piece enjoyer - just know how these warrior type games work before buying this,

The only Pirate Warriors that looks decent natively on PC, but still has plenty of performance issues, and is generally a hard downgrade both mechanically and content-wise from PW3.

This works great as a companion piece after playing 3, which starts at Romance Dawn and ends in Dressrosa with a great list of best-of moments of the series, and representation for plenty of weaker ones too.

Meanwhile, PW4 compounded everything down to only 2 arcs pre-timeskip (Alabasta and Enies Lobby) and threw out the rest, cutting down the cast significantly. In return, they focus more on the contemporary-at-the-time Whole Cake and Wano arcs, but these haven't held up as well and suffer from a lot of "new at the time, stale after a year" appeal characters, like all 7 members of Germa 66 being playable with unique mechanics, to a point of selling them as preorder incentive!

The new mechanics aren't good, either. PW3 is probably the best Musou I know specifically BECAUSE it doesn't have any jump or block mechanics, forcing frantic dodges and weaves to stay alive, as well as health pickups to put pressure on. While they kept dodging as necessary and still kept blocking out, they've re-integrated jumping with both attack cancels and air combos, as well as new "Sky" type characters who perpetually stay in the air. It's a flashy mechanic but works miserably against a lot of units who are designed to exist on the ground to begin with.

The new armor system for enemies is fitting for One Piece; notable enemies just ignore attacks and take things on the chin, and it means you have to respect their animations more, but the real crime is level scaling between stages. A 1 level difference between your upgrades and the stage easily means it's a no-sell for you and you'll suffer time penalties just to get rid of one unit that isn't trying especially hard to stop you. It's designed to only be played in order, which would be fine if there was linear branches that made it obvious, but this game has very little in way of content.

Besides the scene-recreation Story Log, your other free play mode is Treasure Log. In PW3, you'd have a map of islands with random assignments to clear to find boss characters to unlock with special maps. In this, it's a similar function, worse UI, putting everything in a numbered list sorted by level. There's maybe 1/4 of the amount of stages to play in this one.

Combined with how many characters were removed due to the changes to combo systems and gameplay mechanics, it's unsurprising many weren't happy with PW4.

I still recommend it because it's good slop and I love my slop, but I'll *STRONGLY* recommend checking out the graphically inferior Pirate Warriors 3 first. It has the spirit, the story, and the gameplay. Just mod the visuals to be on par with the PS4 version and you'll have the best musou possible.

This one's just a half-decent follow-up with bad gimmicks.

This game is the type where you have to fight hordes of weak enemies paired with a few strong ones and there are many mission goals/objectives which give you the win. 

The leveling up system/power system is really cool, all characters share a map where everyone gets upgrades but if you want to upgrade a character to there full potential and unlock more moves you can put points into a specific character map which only boosts that character.

In this game there are skills/special buffs where you can only have a select amount of them so its interesting to think of what you'll need for each character.

There are 4 character types( I think) Power, Runner/Flying, Defense and Technique. Each character type has different pros and cons. Power characters tend to do more damage and runners are really fast.

Transformations:
There are 3 transformations in the game for luffy.
Gears 2, 4 bounceman, 4 snakeman
Gear 2 is only available for pre timeskip because after that gear 2 moves are incorporated into normal fighting.

Gear 3 is only an attack but there are many gear 3 attacks. These attacks do more damage but they take a long time to charge up. Pre timeskip luffy also shrinks after using this attack but this effect is removed after timeskip.

Bounce man and snake man both change Luffy's class to runner.

IMPORTANT:

Some really annoying things about this game are that they skip short or unimportant arcs.
but they do have cut scenes explaining the blanks.
They skip:
The whole east blue
Skypiea
Thriller bark
Fishman island
punk hazard
Zou

This game is still really really good
overall its a 7/10 game for a non one piece fan
but a 9/10 for any one piece fan

If you just want to have a dopamine rush, smash buttons wildly. do funny numbers to thousands of npcs and juggle an innocent marine as a 30ft Whitebeard. There's no other better game. It looks good, it plays good, the combat is surprising varied for how easy and for how many characters there are. There's enough progression that lasts long enough to give you something tangible to go for.

The biggest issue I have is the map design. It is so dumbfounding how they designed most of the maps. Most objectives don't have markers, you have to use your mini map. When you have hundreds of guys to fight, particle effects everywhere covering up a mini map that is already chalk full little icons it can be frustrating trying to figure out where to go. It doesn't show you different levels it just highlights what level your on. I don't need to see which level I'm on I need to find the stair case that takes me to that different level. Being such a fast paced game where their are literal thousands of enemies spawning every second you'd think they want you quickly go between objectives and keep up a combo streak. No they don't. That put objectives on complete opposite sides of maps they design it in such a way where you to go around everything to get to it. You can't jump over environments, invisible walls block pretty much every thing. If an objective is 5m away but there's a railing in the way, you can't just jump over it you have to walk all the way around the map to go the one spot the devs want you to go. For how fast paced the game is it not uncommon to go minutes of game play in total of you just walking around with nothing to do. It is also not uncommon for this hack and slash game to have levels go on for 15/20 minutes which can drag on. 


There is also a lot of small technical issues. The menus are just god awful to navigate. Do you have a mouse and keyboard? Well good luck, there is no mouse support in the menus, you have arrow key to every tab. You can't just click things like a normal game. The lock on is awful it's so slow it actually handicaps you, the camera can't keep up with how quickly you can juggle enemies and throw them across maps so your stuck in a situation where you can't see in front of you but you also can't move the camera. Anytime you use can attack that has a long wind up you can't aim it anywhere, you're stuck in direction you aimed it before. With hundreds of effects, sounds, thousands of npcs, text on screen, it is very easy to miss something and you can't correct your mistake. One could cancel the animation but that just means you dropped your combo and wasted your skill. Combos timers still decay during wind ups and in animations which is a questionable choice.
Good

I recently got into One Piece's manga and read it to completion before playing this. I assume it's on sale because of the Live Action release's hype. I'm a fan of Warriors games, and have played a lot of the crossovers (and none of the actual ones, haha.) 

The game is fun, but not worth $60. It goes on sale for like 1/6th the price or so often, and if you like Warriors games or like One Piece, pick it up then. For more detail, read ahead.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
[list]
[*] Game has a universal, on-command movement option that allows for many different combos and long strings to do. It feels fun and snappy to do in the middle of combat, and is a nice offensive dodge and free combo extension that helps a lot with the power fantasy of Warriors game.
[*] Characters are represented very well, with each character feeling powerful and having their own unique traits and mechanics. Also, a generally pretty large roster of unique characters. 
[*] The Armor System isn't nearly as bad as other reviews have made it out to be. It's a perfectly fine system and it just makes you have to respect the tougher enemies and actually watch out for their attacks and strike at more proper moments. I found it fun to create my openings and then deal as much damage as possible and it made me have to think about when to use my moves more.
[*] Incredibly fun in the Beat'em Up aspect.
[*] Has plenty of non-story missions to do as well in a big side-mode.
[/list]

[h1]The Middling[/h1]
[list]
[*] Some episodes of the main story are just 1v1s with very little substance, and it's pretty boring. It's not bad or hard, just a little lame. I'd rather these not exist at all. Alabasta has the most of these, and for some reason you have to actually play the fight where Luffy does nothing against Crocodile for 3 minutes and then nearly dies in one hit. 
[*] Speaking of mission design, you really can't fail any missions unless you die or a very key-to-that-particular-mission AI companion falls, especially in the main story. If you aren't one to want to strategize, this is fine. But it left me wanting more, especially coming off playing Fire Emblem: Three Hopes.
[*] The game has the repetition you'd expect from a Warriors game. It isn't for everyone, but if you like the source material or Warriors game, it should be fine.
[*] Not everything gets a Story Arc. More on the consequences of this later, but the idea of skipping arcs for the sake of a game is definitely reasonable on the development side.
[*] Fighting Teach sucks. You really get to feel how obnoxious his powers are and he's an enemy you generally do have to play pretty slow against, and he's cowardly as hell. Doesn't dock the game points at all, if anything it represents him well. This is just a silly bulletpoint I felt like including.
[/list]

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
[*] Very small microstutters happen occasionally. I'm a stickler for framerate and lag, and it ultimately didn't bother me that much. I just enabled vsync and then it happened significantly less, mostly just in the low-effort cutscenes. My computer is far over the recommended for the game.
[*] Many arcs get skipped over in the story. I can understand skipping a lot of the East Blue stuff; there isn't much room to work with an arc like Arlong Park in a Warriors game, as good as it is, but... No Fishman Island? No Impel Down?! No Skypiea?! Not only that, but characters like Magellan and Enel are also completely unrepresented. It's a big bummer, especially given both of them are absolutely primed for Musou-styled gameplay with their gigantic and dangerous attacks as seen in the animanga. 
[*] This is a big one for me. You only pick one character to play as per mission, and cannot change in the middle of one. Not only this, but you cannot issue orders to any allied playable characters for that mission. This means that you're pretty much entirely on your own as the one character you pick. This also greatly hurts any sort of strategy element the game could actually have, discourages playing as and investing time and knowledge into multiple characters, and the overall mission design being far more simplistic. If you've played another game with these elements, you're definitely going to miss them, especially when every character in this game is generally really cool. I don't regret sticking with Luffy wherever I could for the main story, as he kind of just does everything, especially mobility once you get Boundman. It was the best thing I could really do to fill the void of being able to be in several different places at once with multiple characters, as there are plenty of objectives that will just spawn on the opposite side of the map from you. 

So overall, I think it's missing some key characters, and the actual strategy is really done away with and you can only play as one character per mission as really the biggest flaws with the game. If you can deal with that, on top of the usual Musou button-mashy beat'em up style gameplay, you'll like this game.

This is by far the most fun One Piece game i have played to this date, the combat is absolutely amazing to say the least, the moves the characters all amazing if you like hoard games your going to love this, if you love One Piece your going to love this. Edit after finishing all the missions and achievements: this game is still absolutely breath taking, after going through every treasure log and getting S rank i can say that there are some issues if you can even call it that, it mostly has to do with the strength of each character, for example Whitebeard and Kaido are by far the 2 strongest characters in this game (Smoothie doesn't compare i have tried her a decent amount and she just inst as unstoppable as those 2) while other characters struggle on the later stages despite being fully upgraded and having OP traits, i do want to play some other characters to fully 100% the game (by maxing every character and getting every coin) but for level 14 stages and above you just don't do enough damage or you get bounced around like a balloon because of this alone it is a little disappointing if you wanted to go through the entire treasure log with a character like Brook because he cannot hold his own on these stages. Despite all that mentioned i am very happy with the game and am excited for whenever they release more stages and or characters (Onigashima Luffy hype)

I enjoy this game because I'm a One Piece fan. The gameplay, music, combos, and more are great. However, the issue here is that when I play and manually save my games, it seems that the game doesn't save my files. Just earlier, I upgraded a hero, and when I manually saved and turned off the game, then logged back in, the hero I upgraded reverted to a lower level. This isn't the first time, but it has happened repeatedly. In the past, I uninstalled the game due to this issue. Now, after reinstalling and playing again, the game still has the same problem as before. It's wasting my time. It's about the game's save files where I've played for dozens of hours, and the hero I upgraded and the items I obtained are lost just like that.

[h1]The best combat gameplay so far![/h1]
　If Pirate Warriors 3 didn't have port problems, it would have outperformed Pirate Warriors 4 in terms of content. Pirate Warriors 4 was good in terms of gameplay and its port, but it lacked content. about gear 5th lets talk:

[H3]Review :[/h3]
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]　　About[/th]
        [th]　　Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Gʀᴀᴘʜɪᴄ[/td]
        [td]　
　Since this is the newest game, of course, it has better visuals than any previous installment. OPPW4 brings the best character scaling and color scheme, which looks different for each map. Not to mention, the close-up cutscenes look better than any previous PW game. As for its new UI, though, I think PW3 still holds the trophy. it looks more stylish than this game. It may look clean, but when it comes to the character select screen, it doesn't really look mind-blowing. However, the rest of the graphics are outstanding.
　[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Gᴀᴍᴇᴘʟᴀʏ[/td]
        [td]　
　As a PW player, this game does hold the best gameplay in the series. I'm kinda disappointed they removed the Kizuna Rush from PW3. now our allies are useless AF. Of course, the new technique equipment was the best feature, and I think it should carry over into the next PW series. The only reason why this game gets positive reviews, as in my cover review, is because the combat saves this game a lot. It's the most solid One Piece Pirate Warrior combat I've ever played.
　[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Mᴜʟᴛɪᴘʟᴀʏᴇʀ[/td]
        [td]　
　Most people prefer single player. Additionally, the multiplayer mode doesn't really add new gameplay. I can't say much about the connection, but that's all I can say. I mean, why don't they just make a separate all-online room like many modern games? Searching for a room with specific categories won't help. and its dead.
　[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Cᴏɴᴛʀᴏʟ[/td]
        [td]　
　After getting tortured with controller issues in PW3, PW4 is supporting many inputs than PW3, and it works so well you don't need to mess with Steam community custom controller inputs. So far, D-input works just fine.
　[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Pʟᴀʏᴛɪᴍᴇ[/td]
        [td]　
　Up to 15-24 hours compared to the previous game, thanks to its best mode called Dream Log that makes the game last about 100 hours. This game is shit. and it will be always a fact even if they added new DLC up to 100 DLC without new mode it just useless.
　[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Sᴛᴏʀʏ[/td]
        [td]　
　Here's the main problem with PW4. You know, most PW games started from the beginning up to the newest arc (except PW2, that game never existed). PW3 had all of it until the Dressrosa arc. I mean, if you want to experience One Piece without reading the manga and anime, go play PW3. But if you want to get into OP and play PW4, go ahead, but these games remove most arcs, and even gathering the crew doesn't exist here. PW3 > PW4, and that remains a fact!

　Besides the story mode, we should talk about other modes. In PW3, they had Dream Log, a mode where you can take your selected character adventuring on islands to reach the last island where Shank is the final boss. In PW4, bye-bye, no content for you! Instead, you got Treasure Log that's so bad; it only throws random stuff at you! The map changes whenever you reset the menu and has no purpose at all, besides collecting meaningless coins. In PW3 Dream Log, you can unlock new characters, which is the best and has so many collectibles compared to PW4. Overall, OP4 was more like an arcade-like game, not really worth it for its story and content but only for using your favorite characters to battle enemies, that's all.
　[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]

　•　Character paywall with no additional content.

　[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]DLC[/td]
        [td]　
　Ah yes, I played this game before the Gear 5 Luffy trailer came out, and as far as I can see, the game now became a money grab. There are no additional new modes, just random favorite characters you already have, but with new costumes and techniques, and now it's time to grind endlessly without any purpose. I remember PW3 had so much content that DLC has costumes. This game has no content and releases costumes that don't change anything, but let's see, still i bet they wont have new mode. so not worth even for OP fans.

　Our main discussion is: Why do we need to pay for Gear 5 Luffy? We bought this game, and we're getting nothing new—no story updates or new arcs. It feels like a waste of money! we might as well wait for PW5. At least Yamato and uta was worth it but not at that price, but what about the rest of the cast? Young Rayleigh and young Garp? And what's the point of having OP Red Movie Shank again? I know they are just leaked characters, but it definitely feels like a money grab.

[h1]The 100% One Piece:Pirate Warriors 4 Review[/h1]

[table]
[tr]
[td][b]Pros[/b][/td]
[td][b]Cons[/b][/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Huge roster of characters from the One Piece universe to play as[/td]
[td]The game can feel repetitive after extended play sessions[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Colorful and vibrant visuals that capture the essence of the One Piece anime and manga[/td]
[td]The story mode can be short and lack depth compared to other musou games[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Exciting and satisfying combat mechanics that are easy to pick up and play[/td]
[td]Some players may find the camera angles and movement to be disorienting and difficult to control[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Cooperative multiplayer mode that allows players to team up and take on challenges together[/td]
[td]The game can feel too easy, lacking the challenge that many players look for in action games[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Great fan service for One Piece fans, with many iconic moments and locations from the series being faithfully recreated[/td]
[td]The game's music and sound design can feel repetitive and lacking in variety[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td][/td]
[td]The game's story mode is not fully voice acted, which can detract from the immersive experience[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td][/td]
[td]Some players may find the lack of innovation and new features compared to previous Pirate Warriors games to be disappointing[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h3][b]Conclusion:[/b][/h3]

One Piece: Pirate Warriors 4 is an action-packed musou game with a huge roster of characters from the One Piece universe to play as. The game's colorful and vibrant visuals capture the essence of the One Piece anime and manga, making it a treat for fans of the series.

The game's combat mechanics are easy to pick up and play, offering exciting and satisfying gameplay. The cooperative multiplayer mode also allows players to team up and take on challenges together.

However, the game can feel repetitive after extended play sessions, with some players finding the camera angles and movement to be disorienting and difficult to control. The story mode can also be short and lack depth compared to other musou games, leaving players wanting more.

Furthermore, some players may find the lack of challenge in the game to be disappointing, with the game feeling too easy. The music and sound design can also feel repetitive and lacking in variety, detracting from the overall experience. The game's story mode is also not fully voice acted, which can be a drawback for players looking for a fully immersive experience.

Despite these drawbacks, One Piece: Pirate Warriors 4 is a great choice for fans of the One Piece series, offering great fan service and faithfully recreating many iconic moments and locations. However, for players looking for innovation and new features compared to previous Pirate Warriors games, the game may feel lacking.

I recommend this game to One Piece fans, as it has that sensation; you fight the masses, you fight the bosses, you have the moves, you talk the talk and you walk the walk. The graphics style is niche; clay-realism with black anime-esque outlines. Gorgeous!

But if we turn our eyes away from Nami's chest area, I would not recommend this game in general because:
- While they updated skill mechanics and unlockables via the really creative islands, the game is just a pure downgrade of PW3.
- Graphics are nicer than the first PC PW3 game but I miss that comic-style cutscene direction. I really thought they knew they had something good there and would build upon it.
- Returning to the cut argument, while you have a lot of playable characters with a lot of specific things to do to unlock it all, PW3's content of characters and maps was just far more magical.
- They know fully well they could sell the One Piece story to us a thousand times over yet they decided to release a high priced game to us that is basically just a technical preview of what the previous version could have been if they tried.
- One Piece Pirate Warriors 5 needs to learn from these mistakes, because the Musou genre is perfect for the world. You need to feel OP against the masses and only bosses should be a challenge, it digs that, it just needs balance. It also needs far more depth, JRPG depth, food, training mechanics, fishing, exploration, Straw Hat Fleet mechanics, I could come up with more and more and it would all still fall into place with this story-telling Warriors-like game.

All in all... If you want a PC re-sensation of One Piece, play Pirate Warriors 3 rather. It has issues in regards to high fps, resolution and controler support but they can be fixed. It's giant in comparison to this 4th entry, sadly or rather in the perspective of that game, luckily, you'll have the awesome Arlong moments and Fishman Island story, more Sanji and Zoro, the important parts! ... a ton more of the very important story details in short. Games will always flop if the next entry isn't an expansion, developers please, try to finally understand this fact. We've had enough paint thrown over our eyes. Something as big as One Piece deserves respect from all of us. Never cut; only expand! Take the good you had going, remove the bad and tedious, come up with new streamlined ideas. Make it a 250gb game, I'll happily download it. Just gimme the perfect One Piece Video Game experience in the next entry, please, this genre is *made* for this; all it truly needs is clever balance and more of everything.

Title: One Piece: Pirate Warriors 4 - A Swashbuckling Adventure Worth Sailing For

Rating: ★★★★☆

One Piece: Pirate Warriors 4 is a captivating and action-packed musou game that takes players on an exhilarating journey through the vast and colorful world of the popular anime and manga series, One Piece. Developed by Omega Force and published by Bandai Namco Entertainment, this fourth installment in the Pirate Warriors series offers an improved and polished experience that will satisfy both fans of the franchise and musou game enthusiasts alike.

The game's biggest strength lies in its faithful adaptation of the One Piece universe. With a vast roster of over 40 playable characters, each possessing their own unique fighting style and abilities, Pirate Warriors 4 captures the essence of the series and allows players to unleash their favorite character's iconic moves in flashy and satisfying combat. From Monkey D. Luffy's rubbery punches to Roronoa Zoro's deadly swordplay, the gameplay remains true to the source material, making every battle a joy to experience.

Sure, I'd be happy to provide a review for One Piece Pirate Warriors 4.

Released in March 2020 for multiple platforms, including PS4, Xbox One, and Nintendo Switch, One Piece Pirate Warriors 4 is the fourth entry in the One Piece Pirate Warriors series. The game is a hack-and-slash action game that follows the story of the popular anime and manga, One Piece.

One of the standout features of One Piece Pirate Warriors 4 is the vast roster of playable characters. The game features over 40 characters from the One Piece universe, each with their own unique move set and abilities. Fans of the series will enjoy being able to play as their favorite characters.

The gameplay in One Piece Pirate Warriors 4 is fast-paced and exciting. Players control various characters from the One Piece universe and fight their way through hordes of enemies. The combat is easy to pick up and play, with simple combos and special moves that can be executed with ease.

The game's story mode follows the events of the anime and manga, allowing players to experience the main story arcs of the series in a condensed format. The game also includes a variety of side missions and challenges, giving players plenty of content to keep them entertained.

The graphics and visual effects in One Piece Pirate Warriors 4 are also noteworthy. The game features vibrant, cartoonish graphics that capture the look and feel of the anime. The animations are smooth and fluid, and the game is filled with over-the-top special effects that add to the spectacle of combat.

Overall, One Piece Pirate Warriors 4 is a fun and enjoyable game that fans of the One Piece series will appreciate. The vast roster of playable characters, fast-paced combat, and vibrant graphics make it a worthy addition to the series.

[h1] Great ground work, could use some love in some areas: OPPW3 had more costumes & less clunky movesets. [/h1]
Definitely one of the better warriors games, but I wish there were more move slots, skill slots, & that you would do more damage by endgame (Was really hoping I could one shot with Katakuri's mochi anemone or White Beard's super for example by end game with all damage passives equipped, w/ maxed out damage coins) I personally was just a little disappointed by the lack of oomf in supers in general.

Also I was pretty disappointed by how some characters were either shortchanged with skills & transformations (Such as Carrot Frankie & debatably Chopper not getting transformations; but Big Mom, Kaido, & Luffy did get transformations), lack of costumes, or straight up being worse than in OPPW3 (I personally found Tashigi & the Fujitora to be a lot more enjoyable in OPPW3), or just outright terrible (I'm like never going to play as Boa Hancock, she legitimately has the worst moveset in the game imo). Oh & they removed a few characters from the previous game such as Perona, RIP Perona.

Apart from all of that I still feel like out of all the Warriors games I've played, I still feel like Fire Emblem Warriors, Hyrule Warriors, DW7EL, & DW PsVita probably all handled enemy captains better; I was never particularly thrilled to run into any captains, & never felt challenged in any recent warriors game, pretty much it boiled down to just needing better stats in this OPPW4 or the other OPPW3, or just running off to find a medkit (meat/food), or just playing as a factually better character (Like Big Mom, or Katakuri who can heal themselves & deal great damage).

If anything the combat encouraged playing as the "OP" characters, since you want to deal with the regenerating "health bar" quickly & having a self heal makes things significantly easier, it just felt like if you wanted to have any fun you had to give up a few skill slots to damage boosting so you could tear through the armored health bar thing faster so you could beat a stage in a reasonable amount of time. And I am still very annoyed by the "victory conditions have changed" thing where every stage is just constantly dragged out, does it really hurt to let us know how much time we will be spending on a stage, like come on, sometimes I just want to get my upgrades or money & move on instead of having to randomly commit to a long mission.

As for the new types I personally didn't like it, it really didn't make a whole lotta sense: For instance Luffy's Snake Man is a Speed type, but his Bound Man is a sky type, yet the Sky type moves faster & can hold the dash button to fly across the map, but Snake Man has to spam the dash button (And snake man has a problem doing damage or connecting hits so he isn't that great either really). This same issue is sorta across the board as Kizaru & Big mom both in sky type forms can dash infinitely, but speed type characters seemingly cannot. Then when it comes to movesets it feels like Technique types are always Clunky, & Strength types are always robbed of any aerial moves, so sky types tend to be both faster & more versatile than everyone else.

I will say I really liked the addition of being able to equip moves onto characters, but I wish we were able to equip another 4 to the other trigger, I just find it odd that we have so many unused buttons, & that captain fights have not gotten more intelligent, it pretty much boils down to spamming attacks & having better stats & running off to heal when necessary still.

All in all, I feel this warriors game is worth your time, it has the groundwork to be a great game, but falls just short of being great by taking a few steps forward from past titles (selectable moves, better graphics, larger characters & enemies, destructible environments) & a few steps back (Armored health bars, clunkier movesets, less costumes, not everyone gets aerial combos, not everyone can hold dash, not everyone gets transformations, cut characters & stories, difficulty largely based on stats rather than skill).

One Piece: Pirate Warriors 4 is an amazing game that captures the spirit of the beloved anime series perfectly. The story mode is an epic adventure that follows the Straw Hat Pirates as they search for the ultimate treasure, the One Piece. The game features stunning visuals and an intense action-packed combat system. You'll be able to team up with other characters from the show and take on hordes of enemies at once. The game also features a wide variety of weapons and abilities, allowing you to customize your playstyle. All in all, One Piece: Pirate Warriors 4 is an amazing game that successfully brings the beloved anime to life. The story mode is captivating and the combat is intense and satisfying. The visuals are stunning and the game offers a wealth of content, from the story mode to the online multiplayer mode. All in all, One Piece: Pirate Warriors 4 is an amazing game that any fan of the series will love.

After playing a decent amount, I actually really enjoy this game. All of the characters are pretty faithful to the actual story, as well as having a lot of different environments and unlockable moves. The game is pretty grindy, so it can get really easy to burnout, which is what happened to me. But I can't deny that for the most part it's really fun to just go apeshit with some of the more broken/destructive characters. Big Mom and Kaido actually feel like complete powerhouses, without being so broken that it starts to become boring and braindead to play them. Although I wish some characters were a lot better like Usopp and Chopper. Usopp is my favorite Straw Hat in the story, but he is by far my least favorite character to play in this game due to how weak he is. Another negative that I have is that I wish that there was a lot more stuff that could've been added in. Because of the fact they put every single Vinsmoke brother in the game, I feel like they could've at least added in some other fan favorites, with some of them already being in the game as different AI. I will have a list of all the stuff I wish was in the game, but overall I think this is a great game for both One Piece fans as well as Dyansty Warriors fans, due to the fact that anime powers can make everything feel way more fun and chaotic. 

Stuff I wish that were playable in the game:
-Bon Clay
-Rayleigh
-Moria
-Magellan
-Nekomushi and Dog Viper
-Yamato
-Kuma 
-Garp
-Perona
-Enel
-Caesar Clown
-Bellamy
-Hody Jones
-Literally any costumes for Chopper, Robin, Franky, Brook (Seriously where are they?)
-Costumes and Characters from Pirate Warriors 3

It took me 16 hours to complete the story mode and about half of that time I already got more than half of the achievements.

Here are some recommendations if you plan on getting this game:

- You don't need any particular strategy to beat any boss, just button smashing and a bit of running around. No decision making, no secrets, just plain hack & smash and a bit of grinding for coins and money.

- If you get the game with the DLC included, you will get a few characters like Drake and Oden than can help you farm S rank easily on those hard and pesky missions. But if you don't get any DLC, you can wait until you unlock Luffy (with fourth gear) Whitebeard or Ichiji-- they are fairly powerful. 

- I totally recommend anybody to play this game on Hard difficulty. Normal is way too easy. The boss is literally standing in front of you, walking around waiting for your attacks if you play on Normal. 

- Playing with a controller is highly recommended, seriously, playing on a keyboard will give you carpal tunnel. 

- The One Piece is real.

This game is not Pirate Warriors 3

Yes, you still grind to get coins although its way stripped down and linear (but less frustrating). Yes, there is fan service. No, there are no Kizuna Attacks. 

Character progression has been jazzed up with a sphere grid-esque tree of upgrades per character. Each character now fits some pretty well-defined sub-classes that provide some variety to play styles. Personally I think the Sky characters are really overpowered and can stunlock and then decimate pretty much anything with the right upgrades. I mean that in the best way; Musou is at its best when you've broken it.

Stages are ugly and confusing in their layout, par for the course here.

I like all the new improvements to character differentiation and the new special moves system is a great way to swap out big flashy moves to use on command instead of trying to remember the attack string.

[h1]PLAY ONE PIECE: PIRATE WARRIORS 3 IF YOU WANT STORY![/h1]

Pros:
*Redefining [b]fast[/b] paced action for Musou/Warrior titles
*A moderate cast of characters with 4-5 different play styles
*CO-OP mode!

Cons:
*Skips several arcs, a few important for character's development, others not so much
*several cut characters, playable and non playable
*coby is still not playable
*broken english (as per usual) as well as broken character names ("koby" and "teech", i'm surprised they didn't go with "ruffy" instead of luffy)

One Piece: Pirate warriors 4 absolutely knocks it out of the park with it's amazing gameplay mechanics and speed, not to mention different skills for you to costumize your favorite character with your favorite abilities instead of the locked 2 special attacks you had in previous ones. To say OPPW 4 is bad is an understatement, even if it cuts content in favor of gameplay.

This game is a must have if you wish to experience what musou/warriors series have come to, and being a fan of this type of game, It brings a tear to my eye to be able to experience such a master piece of modern gameplay <3

Now, if you wish it to do some justice to the story, I'd suggest playing the third

It's a good game if you're a fan of button mashers and enjoy the one piece story. I 100% it fairly easily would have liked it if it included more missions from the earlier arcs from the beginning but did the latter half of One Piece justice.

Saying it's worse than Pirate Warriors 3 is like saying a banana split with chocolate syrup on it is worse than a banana split with butterscotch syrup on it. You're still getting a banana split, it's still delicious, and it's really all down to personal taste.

This game slaps, but I'm a butterscotch kinda guy. One thing I really don't like about it, though it's not a game breaker, is how much looser the combat feels compared to its predecessors -- you really feel like, especially with speed and sky-type characters, you're just zooming around almost to the point of being out of control. I haven't played as all of the characters yet, so I can't really say I've settled into one I enjoy deeply, but as a result I'm finding myself playing as a wider variety of characters compared to earlier titles *because* I haven't settled into a main. The characters I usually play as have been changed dramatically (Sanji) or gutted to an unfortunate degree (Tashigi), so finding a new one is a bit of an ongoing effort, I'd say.

The campaign mode is fine, it's about as good as any of the PW games' campaigns are, though I really do miss PW1's more linear, mission-type layouts with obstacles to overcome and problems to solve compared to later games' more traditional musou play. I didn't realize how much I missed that kind of musou game until I played P5 Strikers, actually. PW4 being a more traditional musou game like PW3 but without the *impact* you feel with your attacks and without some real army-clearing attacks like the Kizuna follow-ups makes it feel a lot less dynamic as a result. The fact that there's not much free-play or mission mode like PW3's is also a point against it.

But, where the game falters is also where it really kicks up something new and interesting by comparison. If you're a grindfest kinda guy like I am, the new character upgrade maps are a treat and make you feel like you're really advancing a character unlike PW3's coin system. The giant enemies are fun as heck to take down even on harder difficulties, where you'd expect them to just be HP sponges, and they add a layer of strategy to the greater map design that I really enjoyed. Overall, I would say the feeling of taking down a giant and capturing territories in this game is about as fun and high-pressure as getting Kizuna score was in PW3, and I'm a lot more thankful of how much less stressful S-Ranking a map is in this one.

Game's solid, definitely a recommend.

But man, they really did my boy Sanji dirty. Though, if you were playing Sanji in Pirate Warriors games to begin with, you're already a special kind of masochist, I suppose.

The good:
+ Gameplay and new movesets for many characters feel more fluent and devastating than PW3.
+ New giant type enemies are fun to fight.
+ The biggest roster of playable characters with 43 in the base game and 9 DLC.
+ New, bigger maps with the new building-destruction mechanic really help sell the power fantasy.
+ Better visual and effect when compared to PW3.
+ Great music.

The bad:
- Lock-on camera is god awful at times
- Many playable story arcs like Arlong, Thriller park, Fishman island in PW3, are either removed or reduced into recap cutscenes in PW4.
- With the revamped gameplay, the kizuna rush mechanic is gone, I can't say if this is for the better or worse in term of gameplay but without it, a somewhat unique aspect of characters' interactions is gone.
- Less alternate outfits for many characters.
- Dream logs' interface is severely downgraded from an interactive map to a simple selection menu.
- No more treasure events, legend diary or anything that would encourage you to replay story missions except for getting S grade.
- Some maps can be quite annoying to navigate.
- The new buildings-destruction system feel somewhat underused, like i was hoping to be able to create new routes on some maps and not just dealing extra damage to enemies.

Overall:
- Is this a good musou game? Yes.
- Is this game a good sequel to PW3? Absolutely not, if anything this is more PW3.5 than a full sequel.
- Should you try this out knowing nothing about One piece? Maybe not, many of the main story arcs are greatly abridged or glossed over.
- Should you try this out as a One Piece fan? Yes, but i highly recommend getting this on sale.

Possibly the greatest game of the 21st century, putting it ahead of EDF 5, Warriors Orochi 3, 4, and Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen. An applause for Koei, as this entry in the Warriors series is the best to date IMO. They do a good job in following the main plot points in the One Piece story. Combat is smooth, impactful, and flashy as ever. The roster is deep, and 90% of the roster feels great and unique (Bege and Bartolomeo are especially dog shit). The environments are well crafted and are interesting to navigate. My main issue with this game, is the omission of a few playable characters that were present in the OPPW3 roster, especially Enel and Caesar Clown. It was a shame to see some of the most fun characters from OPPW3 go away, regardless this game is great, get it if you are interested in the Warriors series or a fan of One Piece. You won't be disappointed.

I love One Piece as a fan who's entering his 15th~ year as a watcher and avid fanboy. I got given OPW3 from someone dear to me in my life who died a year later so I was really excited to finally own OPW4 and I found that there's a few improvements but a lot taken away at the same time.

The storymode is ridiculously short compared to OPW3. We got to explore all the major arcs from our first encounter with Buggy all the way to Dressrosa in OPW3, here we get a whistlestop tour of some places with the biggest focus being on alabasta, giving us this impression we'll see the same experience as OPW3 with the storyline just to be disappointed and rugpulled. I've completed 4 stories worth about 10 stages each and I'm basically at the last story. It took me way longer to get this far in OPW3.

The character progression feels more involved in this game, with us now being able to unlock, upgrade and swap out character skills to build a cooler feeling experience and allowing a difference in playing which OPW3 didn't have (which made combat feel samey). Let's get into the important bit.

I am not anywhere near done so IDK the full list of characters compared to OPW3, I am hoping it's added rather than taken away but I would say I feel that removing the amount of storyline they did for the sake of adding a plethora of characters which most people won't ever touch, whilst also robbing us of the opportunity to see explored arcs post-Dressrosa feels... Like OPW is quickly turning into the new Call of Duty to cash grab on the fanbase every few years.

It's very Simple, Do you like One Piece? Okay well as far as OP fan service goes these games are king. The Roster is pretty expansive, the story mode is pretty much just an abridged version of the anime/manga with a very different Wando Arc (if you're watching or reading the Arc Proper right now this game WILL NOT SPOIL anything). The DW setup works far better for One Piece than a generic fighter style game in the vain of DB Xenoverse or any of the Naruto Ninja Warrior games, If you are looking for that kind of game this is not it. This game is you picking your fav OP character and trashing literally hundreds of enemies on screen. The Core Straw hat Crew has alt costumes, Sanji and Luffy arguably having the most. And every character plays unique.

Positives:
+ Musou game is a good fit for One piece as the characters within said series are OP as hell and could defeat an entire army
+ The ability to transform some Character types are really fun, as different forms can really change up their gameplay style
+ The Wano arc is a unique take, as its original to the game and has some fun ideas in itself (its also interesting to see an alternative ending to Wano and compare it to the actual ending it had)

Negatives:
- GLITCHES, especially animated Cut scenes. When said scenes occur the screen turn blank and resumes to gameplay when it should've had cut scenes within it. I realized this was a glitch after Marine Ford.*
-Some arcs are really skimmed over making the pacing feeling odd (Definitely do not use this to catch up to One Piece)
-Steam Workshop support would've been nice

*A fix for it that worked for me was turning the game into windowed 720p and use ALT+Enter to make it into full screen, this way the cut scenes Play out normally (hope this fix works for you)

Final thoughts:
Highly recommend this game to One Piece Fans as it gives an fun Recap of the One Piece up to Whole Cake (The Wano here is original to the game, but nonetheless still interesting).
Definitely pick this up during a Sale.

If you're a fan of "Warriors Game" such as the Dynasty Warriors series, Samurai Warriors series, Warriors Orochi Series, etc., There are plenty to love about this game like on how all the character fells very different from one another, on how the gameplay is very fun... repetitive... but very fun.

If you're a fan of One Piece and follow the stories through Shows and Manga and don't mind how they compress and skip most of the story. This game is something you will enjoy. It even have some original story on "Wano Arc" since the game was release before the conclusion of the saod arc.

But if you are not a fan og any of those then i don't think you will have a great time with this game... You can still have fun but you will get bored fast specially on how repetitive a warrors game is and on how they skip most of the one piece seriess arc.

And as for me after completing the main story and some of the of its other content i can safely say that i did enjoy my time playing the game... But there are something I need to address about the game... First, on how grindy the game is for maxing a character... Most warriors game are very grindy but the way they changed the level system on this take that gindyness of those game to a whole new level. Second, this is not just for this game but dor the whole warriors game series... Why does every time a sequel come out rather than balancing and upgrading all tha character and adding additional new one you always have to remove old characters? And lastly speaking of balancing... It's okay to have some OP character that will steamrolled tha game since there are only a few that can be call OP... But those character whom you only going to use once because on how bad they are on everything that they do. Those should be fix.

Overall, the game is very fun and very much recommended... But i do recommend to get it on sale.

The game is fun but gets very repetitive later on. There are a lot of improvements but there are a few problems I have with the game. First problem is the main Campaign feels short. That's because they cut off a lot of the Arcs from like East Blue, Sky Island, Thriller Bark, Impel Down, Fish Man Island, and Punk Hazard. The game reuse a lot of the models and animation during cutscenes, not movie cutscenes. Second problem is they removed like about 7 playable characters from the previous, Enel, Kuma, Garp, Perona, Magellan, Moria, and Caeser. While the roster of playable characters in this game is bigger, yes, even with the DLC characters, it is a downgrade by removing (or in this case replacing) previous playable characters. Third problem is they removed Kizuna Rush and replaced it with Full Force Burst but without the APC characters appearing at the end of your combo strings and combination cinematic attack. Some people dislike them and some people like me like them. I enjoy looking at the different combination attacks cinematics and having APC attack with you at the end of a combo string makes them feel alive. In this game, allies APC are useless and boring. Fourth problem is the DLCs. I didn't buy the DLCs mostly because they're pointless, in my opinion. They should had added additional maps and Arcs for the DLC. But instead we get more playable characters which doesn't add any replayability to me after finishing the game. If the characters DLC were like 5 or 6 USD I guess they're worth it. The new improvements they added are as follow. You can jump, customize your character's Skills and Special Skills loadout, and they removed the Treasure Events. This is a musou type game with a One Piece skin slapped on it. You either like One Piece and/or Musou games or you don't. I like both but eventually it starts to feel very repetitive like I said earlier. Not worth full price. At least 20 to 30 USD.

ONE PIECE: PIRATE WARRIORS 4 isn't the best in the Pirate warriors franchise, however it is really fun for One piece fans who know the material.

Pirate warriors 4 only cover 6 main arcs that are in One Piece. 

Meaning it's missing ALOT of content that was in previous games. The Arcs included are Alabasta, Enies Lobby, the Paramount War, Dressrosa, Whole Cake Island, and a game original Wano arc that has nothing to do with the actual Wano Arc because it's missing key characters and things that happen in Wano, so its not just an original story about Wano...Its just a set of missions were Kaidou has a loose connection and it's called Wano because of that.


None the less Pirate warriors 4 does a great job at being a fun Dynasty Warriors type game with One piece characters, It's still really fun and while not having a massive amount of content it plays better than other Pirate warrior games by far and i did have alot of fun with it despite the missing of some of the most important arcs in the series...*cough cough* dressrosa.

7/10 Just buy Pirate warriors 3 however if you really dont care and just want mindless fun with One Piece characters then go for it.

Cons: short campaign mode, thin roster of playable characters compared to Pirate Warriors 3.

In my opinion, its a much better improvement compared to Pirate Warriors 3. Way more comboes, and a easy flashy super move you can do with the crazy combo attacks is very fun overall! Its only fun like this, but sadly you have to grind individually for each character in order to unlock all their combos and moves, which is ridiculous cause of how long the grind is. But if you manage to level them all up, and play them normally, it becomes a really fun game to pull out whenever I wanna kill an hour or 2 for time. Graphics are an improvement, and has quite a bit of options to tweak to compared to pirate warriros 3. And whats even better, the port of this game is good! Your able to actually play the episodes and not having to worry about crashing or being randomly kicked out. The only thing I didn't like was that if u left the game for any reason, you cant save and go right back into action like PW 3 had (tho it wasnt auto save, so i had to manually save to do this) but still better then not being able to save at all. If u play an episode, better hope to god u can finish it before you get called up and have to leave the game. Not only is the grind and progression really slow, the only way to lvl up your characters is to actually load up a game, I found this to be pretty annoying. Much less episodes compared to PW3, PW3 covers mostly all the arcs, and is pretty accurate. PW4 decides to skip some arcs which is sad cuz skypiea was one of my underated favorite arcs, but sad to see its not in the game. Choosing to start at alabasta arc instead of replaying the episodes to get your crew was a smart decision (every arc before alabasta besides arlong was pretty boring im not gonna try to cap) IN conclusion, its a good game. one of the few games where instead of unistalling after finishing the story, I wanna complete the treasure logs in order to unlock the rest of the characters. (cant wait to see how shanks, and black beard plays.) The only other con I would say about this game is some characters are pretty boring to play. Mostly the Technique fighters like robin, and kuzan who by the way u would expect to have cool moves and combos, but his attacks r so fucking sloww! Speed, power, and sky are the only actual fun characters.
8/10 game. wouldve been 10 but no playable woop slap or elisabello ii.

I'm a HUGE Dynasty Warriors fan, and HUGE One Piece fan, and I'm sad to say this game could've been way, way better. It doesn't feel like they put their heart and soul into this like they do for their Dynasty series,

In Dynasty warriors, ALL weapons and playstyles can kick butt and be incredibly fun, flashy, unique. In Pirate Warriors it's not the same at all. You have the play as the big well-known fighters or go home, Chopper for instance has 0 effort put into his mechanics. Despite being THE transformation character of the show, he doesn't hold ANY OF HIS TRANSFORMATIONS and has NO UNIQUE MOVESETS based off his forms, but yet Luffy does. Why? Idfk, makes no sense.

A LOT of characters suffer this, Usopp, Crocodile, many others suffer this lack of ambitious builds. And it's not just me not liking a playstyle, I loved ALL weapons in ALL dynasty warriors because they were all unique, and effective. Chopper is NOT effective AT ALL. I did my absolute best on 1 mission and it took 2 and a half hours. Then I went in it again with a character I didn't try yet, Frankie, and I beat it in 5 minutes. THAT'S ABSURD. What makes it worse, is these characters on back burner all mechanically work closely the same. They're slow, low damage, no arial potential, and only hit 1 small area once in a great while, and have slow combos. 

Another issue is awesome abilities have to be equipped and make you leave behind other abilities. This should be canned and instead introduce complex input systems so all characters can bring in all moves. This alone would make the trash characters more baerable.

Now for online. Online is so badly done, there's a ton of Desync and it makes it that you might as well be playing alone because of this. And it's not flukes or a glitch, it's 100% constantly desynced intentionally. You will NOT fight the same enemy at the same time. Instead you should Parsec and splitscreen this, but that's lame that you have to do this.

Another issue it lacks is lack of character specific campaigns. Dynasty Warriors let you pick any character, stick with them from their perspective, build up, get stronger, and help whatever cause, it was an RPG game. Pirate Warriors has none of this. I get its trying to be true to the story, but they could easily have another gamemode for this. It's a Video Game trying to be like Dynasty Warriors, so where are the golden, tried and true Dynasty Warrior mechanics? They could have AT LEAST a non-cannon alternate mode.

I won't say don't try the game or avoid it, it can be fun with friends, and if your favorite characters are characters like Luffy and anyone who almost beat Luffy then you'll have a great time. But I still give a negative review for how little effort they put in so many loved characters. You either play Emporers, Warlords, or don't play at all because picking Chopper will mean you spend up to 4 hours on a short mission.

It's just not fun. 

You can relive the anime through the singleplayer mode.... if you fail, you are just doomed to restart the entire 
button mashing fest that this game is. 

The moves are cool, it's accurate and detailed, but overall it becomes boring. I cannot bring myself to enjoy this game past 5 minutes of button mashing to defeat an opponent that most of the time looks like they are standing still.  

On top of all that, you will hear several sound clips and see subtitles that you cannot possibly focus on if you want to continue fighting effectively. This is annoying for most players... 

It feels soulless, after defeating several enemies, I cannot stand watching my character move around with my input while sputtering voice lines with zero animations to accompany them. As if whatever they are saying is so unimportant that the developers just slapped it into the game without a care. 

I see this as a failed experiment. I love One Piece, but once again the game fails to live up to the hype.

As a fan of One Piece this game is a really fun way to relive the main story lines. Also I am not a gamer that attempts difficult games, I enjoy playing something that is relaxing after working a long shift and having fun. this game is exactly that. It's challenging enough to stay fun and keep you interested but not too difficult that you'll be dying and replaying bosses  over and over. Truly just a fun enjoyable game. beating up 100s of enemies with different characters and using their different and unique styles of combat is very enjoyable and makes replaying levels fun and interesting. For people like me who want to just sit back, have a good time, but also still want good graphics and gameplay I can't think of another game I've enjoyed so much in recent years.
