[h1] Good mindless button mashing game [/h1]

[b] The Good [/b]
Amazing artwork
- The design of the levels and characters really bring the one piece universe to life
Story
- The story follows the manga (mostly) so not much to say here
Replayable
- Characters require a significant amount of resources to max out, so lots of grinding involved
Lots of signature moves
- Ranging from iconic to flashy, the ultimate moves do not disappoint and are always a joy to unleash

[b] The Bad [/b]
Unbalanced characters and character classes
- Aerial and Tech characters are not viable, and speed types are vastly inferior to strength types.
- Only Akainu, Biscuit, Big Mom, and Kaido are decent
Lacks the rush of PW3
- Marines are beefier this time and the level cap is 50, so enemies don't really go flying unless using the 4 characters listed above
They didn't put in characters that should've been in the game

One Piece Pirate Warriors 4 is an musou game through and through, letting you satisfyingly steamroll hundreds of thousands of enemies single handedly as powerful hero (or villain) characters. But it comes with most of the typical baggage that goes along with that distinction, it’s not the prettiest looking game in the world, there are lots of reused assets from prior games, and outside of a few select boss fights, its hoards of baddies offer very little resistance.

It has the unusual honor of being both one of the best anime-based games and best Warriors games I've ever played. It has its flaws, including the tiresome return of Giant foes and the usual Warriors repetitiveness, but it's a great example of how to reinvigorate something that seems like a tired formula. If you're a One Piece fan or a fan of the Warriors franchise, PW4 is absolutely worth a go. Once you've taken a bite of gum-gum, you won't be able to resist more.

Has a bit of a grind issue, replayablility issue, tech characters largely suck, and kinda spoils a few bits about Wano, but it is fun as hell to go ham as an emperor and cut down hoards of pirates with mere flick of the wrist.

What the game does best, once you unlock all the combos for each character, is the feeling of being a pirate blessed with anime power. By fruit or by will, your enemies will fall to your over the top might. It is also great that everyone feels legitimately like their own character, with no two combo strings feeling like the same function. 

Also, you get to hear the silly otomat laughs of the pirates in their classic Japanese, what's not to like there?

Get the game on sale if fictional pirates that stretch or set fire to things or literally sunder reality by willing it sounds a bit over the top, but this is def a great game. 

You can ignore the markup music dlc though.

This game is an absolute blast. If you're a One Piece fan, or love hack and slash games, this one can really keep you busy. Is easy to pick up and understand, I would say the controls are a little simpler from the third game, now also adding a set of skills that you select for whatever character you are playing (which just lets you select 4 skills available to that character, which include transformations, special attacks, ultimate moves, etc), plus stamina for dashing and jumping, and performing attacks and combos mid air. Each character is really fun on their own way, and the playstyles fit their abilities quite well, and the skill tree is easier to navigate around as it connects all of the stats and skills as different islands, which is honestly just a neat detail. and the story is told well enough to enjoy it, still not good enough to replace the source material, but the cinematics help on doing justice to a lot of iconic moments, that while rushed, they still really have a lot of impact on them. Plus since this game covers less arcs than the last one, there are extra levels covering parts of the story that were not playable before. So yeah, as I said before, if you are a One Piece or and hack and slash fan, this game may just be your cup of tea, for me it was far more addictive than I thought, and I could not recommend it more.

If you've played Pirate Warriors 3 before this one you'll constantly be aware of how much stuff is missing. Most notably are the majority of story arcs both pre and post timeskip (and even in the ones that are included, some plot points are skipped over or changed slightly to help the musou gameplay fit in, so I wouldn't recommend this to someone wanting to catch up to the series with this), but also specific characters (most of the strawhat crew pre-timeskip are unplayable, and their respective costumes aren't available either), and extra content (the gallery shop and Dream Log from 3 have both been removed, with the latter replaced with specific 'what if?' style battles instead). Reading this, you may wonder why I'm recommending it.

The fact is, Omega Force seem to have focused on the depth of what's in the game rather than a wide spread of things to do. Combat is much more developed than in 3, and most characters really feel like a unique, authentic experience to play as. The upgrade tree is now split up into 3 parts, with the first conferring stat upgrades to all of the characters rather than just one specifically, meaning you don't have to grind to enjoy playing as a character you just spent hours trying to unlock. It isn't an extravagant feast of content, but what is here is a lot of fun.

Side note, the background music in this one is honestly really good! I don't have the anime music DLC but with songs like this I don't think it's really needed at all.

Not as much to do in terms of content vs pw3 , several characters have been removed as well as the coin system. However, this is the best "feeling" play system of all the games. It objectively plays better but theres less game. Also, the characters they removed you have to buy back? eh

Online could be better, it's Abit Lacking, Could do with a Lobby system and perhaps letting folks just continue through with Friends as you would other games, but overall the Fighting system has a nice upgrade compared to the third game, the Verticality of movement is a great change and the Amount of customizable moves is a neat addition. The Story is a bit lack luster though, with cutting out major plot points, and some characters don't even have that many Voice lines or Available movement options. 

I can understand cutting back on things for time and not having the material to work with, but it was a better opportunity to just re due the third game, with this engine and landscapes, and Play the same story, with the Full New world arc up to [SPOILERS] instead of rushing through 'SOME' of the main plot points. Cutting out Sky Island and Thriller bark makes Robin and Brook's segments Seem really rushed and out of place when your supposed to care for them.

If the game was supposed to be an introduction to the series it fails hard with how the story is told, and adding some Characters that are towards the end of the Games story in as early as The First mission/Thing you do is a REALLY bad move story wise...

Not to mention cutting out Half the character roster of the main characters just cause they didn't want to fix/finish their Previous game incarnations? Franky, Robin, Chopper, and Brook aren't playable till half way through the game and most of them are with the crew at the first level. They use their moves from the third game, they have their costumes also, but they aren't selectable unless you're playing Free log and are restricted to 'ONLY' playing their New World versions. A terrible move for the sake of Fast forwarding to.... Basically a Black hole where they lost the main story and made up alot of interactions.

This game is mid. It's like an 8 out of 10, which sounds good, but it isn't better than pirate warriors 3, which is a masterpiece of musuo.  The fighting is different, with styles such as flight and speed, and that really ruins some characters, since they fly all the time if they're sky type. the roster is okay, although the DLC leans too heavily into wano, and there is zero reason for them to have taken out characters.  i would still say pirate warriors 3 has the better roster.  the story mode is okay, although very long, and the treasure log system is okay, not near as fun or inventive as dream islands. overall this game feels like it lacks depth, while pirate warriors 3 had a surprising amount.
The only reason i recommend this game at all, is because the steam port of pirate warriors 3 is a ps3 port, which means its garbage and not worth playing.  this port of pirate warriors 4 runs perfectly fine, so shoot for this if you want to get into musuo, one piece, or just want some mindless, albeit sometimes unfun, musuo.

I would give this game a 9/10
These are my personal opinions on each aspect of the game

Graphics: 8/10
- The 3D models are very cool
- The ground textures are pretty wack in some places
- The textures have a below average amount of pixels in them
- Chopper looks adorable
Animation: 9/10
- The animation is pretty darn good
- In the introduction, the scene of kid running towards kaido is pretty cool
- Some of the scenes are a bit odd
Gameplay: 9/10
- The camera movement is a tad bit inconvenient
- Very satisfying combat
- The controls aren't that good but and I got confused with a bit of the tutorial but I changed the keybinds so thats okay
- It has some very cool combat mechanics
Story: 9.5/10
- It's good as a summary of the one piece story but isn't a replacement for the actual manga or show
- It skips some parts of the original story but that's probably for convenience
- Covers the main scenes of each arc

This is my first time playing a musou game. I came in with low expectations thinking I would just be mashing buttons and enjoying the One Piece aesthetic and this is the exact experience that I received, but the gameplay is a bit above what I expected. Unlocking characters, learning their quirks, and leveling them up to take to high level logs is a decent enough gameplay loop to keep you invested for at least a few dozen hours. If you like One Piece, beating the ever-loving **** out of stuff, and doing cool flashy combos, then there's quite a bit here for you. My only complaints are the price, some slightly awkward mechanics (like red burst being seemingly random at times and flying not having any vertical movement options outside of a locked-on dash), and the lack of a few key characters that have no excuse not being in the game (where's Kuma, come on!) Even with these flaws, at sale price, there's enough fun in this game that's worth looking into for all caught-up One Piece fans.

Amazing Game and Visuals

First of all, a disclaimer: This is the first Dynasty Warriors game/spinoff that I have ever owned myself and played more than an hour of. 

So One Piece: Pirate Warriors 4 has one main thing going for it, and then one thing taking away from it. 

Pro: you get to see and play as some of your favorite one piece characters. There is a nice diversity of abilities, all of them signature moves. The character interaction is great with a lot of "what if" moments which are cool to see. 
Con: The game is too easy, especially when you unlock Kaido, who just bulldozes over everything. Granted, I played it on normal mode, but unless you are going for some sort of uber-completionist stuff and get S Rank on the ultra hard difficulty, then I don't see the point of playing once you have completed the treasure log and the story mode.

I prefer Pirate Warriors 3. This game isn't bad, it's really good and might feel better to some than 3.

Pirate Warriors 4 contains 6 major story arcs, Alabasta, Enies Lobby, Summit War, "Entry to the New World!" (Mainly just Dressrosa), Whole Cake Island and Land of Wano (Called game original because they were entrusted to make their own non-canon ending).

So, they skip the entirety of One Piece up until the end of the Alabasta Saga in this game, as compared to Pirate Warriors 3 which starts off at Orange Town. They've opted to focus on these 6 major story arcs in order to provide more structure I think. The thing is that Pirate Warriors 3 is a fantastic recap of One Piece up until Dressrosa, it goes through important arcs. There's no Impel Down, Thriller Bark, Fishman Island or Punk Hazard in this game. 

All of Germa 66 is in this game except for Vinsmoke Judge, you have to buy him as a DLC along with Smoothie and Cracker, who are the only playable Whole Cake Island characters in this game aside from Big Mom and Katakuri. Germa 66 who haven't really done that much in One Piece as of yet, but still they're in the game, but Kuma, Moria, Magellan, Enel, Perona, Caesar and even Garp were cut out despite being in PW3. You were also able to fight Oars as part of Thriller Bark in PW3, that felt really cool the first time, this game doesn't have that.

It just feels weird not having every Warlord as a playable character, I understand cutting out Enel and Perona, maybe even Caesar. Kuma, Moria and Garp should be in the game.

But instead we have every Yonko, Whitebeard, Big Mom, Kaido, Blackbeard and Shanks as playable characters.

We also have almost everyone from the Worst Generation. Of course, Blackbeard, Luffy and Zoro, but also Law, Bege, Kid and Hawkins, with X. Drake, Urouge and Killer being purchased as DLC.

Then there's the third DLC which allows you to play as Kin'emon, Okiku and Oden.

I just find there to be a lot of odd decisions in this game. One thing this game does better is the levelling. In PW3 you had to use different coins on a character in order to increase their stats or unlock a new ability or something. In this game, you have 3 growth maps to follow instead, 1 joint growth map that affects every character, a personal growth map for each character which allows you to unlock new special abilities and new attack combos among some stat increases, as well as a second personal growth map which is exclusively stat increases.

I think it's a huge improvement, but the third growth map feels a bit unnecessary, because it ends up just making your favorite character way stronger than everyone else, which as far as I know could be mandatory if you play the game's Treasure Log long enough. I like versatility and playing different characters, if some of my characters are weaker just because I don't have the money, that just ends up feeling annoying rather than fun.

I don't know, if you put a larger focus on gameplay than story, then this is a fantastic game, I personally feel it just misses out on some things concerning One Piece as a whole, but it's really fun playing your favorite characters from One Piece. It's just sad that they took out certain iconic and important characters. I'm only giving this a thumbs up because it's still braindead fun. But as someone who has own all 3 previous games, it's a HUGE downgrade from it's predecessors (if you played PW3 on PC its an upgrade).

Burst and special moves don't nearly do as much damage as before; this turns bosses into damage sponges that just stay there getting their ass kicked, being thrown through the air left and right for 2 minutes straight. (Remember the satisfaction of clearing an entire room instantly with Enel or Boa in Pirate Warriors 2? Yeah imagine the absolute opposite of that). I understand rebalancing but they went really hard towards the weaker side of things and without improving the enemy ai, it just made things take longer to kill without any real challenge. 

There's also missing characters from previous entries (Perona, Enel, Garp, Magellan, Caesar Clown, Moriah and Kuma), they removed all of the Dynasty Warriors skins, the music is a huge downgrade, the cutscenes look stiff and awkward as all heck, (No neck Kaido) the story goes Alabasta (yes it starts there) > Enies Lobby> Marineford > Sabody  > Dressrosa > Whole Cake Island > Wano... it just really feels like a beta more than the actual finished product.

As a big fan of one piece, this game makes me super happy just playing it. My only concern is that they skip  a few arc whihc is understandable but i think they missed a few key arcs but other than that its an immensively addictive game

Please note, I have not played any previous Pirate Warriors titles, but have greatly enjoyed Dynasty Warriors since PS2.

With that said, One Piece Pirate Warriors 4 is a far cry from being a decent Warriors game and I am increasingly disappointed that I didn't refund when I had the chance. This game is definitely more for fans of One Piece then Warriors.

The greatest sin of this game is the most vile any piece of entertainment can commit, and that is being boring. The game play relies entirely on repeatedly pommeling the same clone enemies over and over. But that isn't atypical of a warriors title. The real problem is with officer fights. They are absolutely terribly done and expectantly numerous, some levels only consisting of the player fighting an officer. 

Not only is EVERY SINGLE officer an absolutely tank that does basically nothing while you pummel them for several minutes straight but, to add to this tedium, EVERY SINGLE officer has magic shields that make them invincible until you bring them down, with, of course, more pummeling. Even then, you do so little damage that you're just constantly spamming the same attacks for minutes on end. Then, TO TOP IT ALL OFF, invincibility shields regenerate, causing the player to have to continue their ceaseless pummeling to bring them down once more to chip off another embarrassingly small bit of the enemies actual health bar.

This might sound like a small gripe to the uninitiated, but know that every map requires the defeat of numerous officers, sometimes over a dozen and each and every one requires the same exact treatment. It never changes. It was exceptionally lazy on the part of the developers and this constant throughout the game has completely killed what interest I had in the series.

While not terribly familiar with the One Piece story, I get the feeling that a GREAT deal is skipped over during the 'story mode' leading to confusion and a disinterest in that as well. Further, the character selection remains very limited, despite other characters being present and playable in other modes, which I found not only stifling but baffling.

Overall, a very disappointing experience and complete waste of time and money in my opinion. Even on a significant sale, I would not recommend this to anyone I respect.

Firstly, this is my first pirate warriors game, but not my first warriors game.

As a one piece fan, I love this game and its portrayal of these beloved characters. The abilities are a great way to encapsulate one piece attacks and transformations flow smoothly into combat with great effect. 

But, this game is lacking in one way compared to the warriors games I remember from my childhood. A campaign map where I can conquer territory while fighting other commanders throughout the land. Game modes like this were the reason i got so hooked on games like samurai warriors back in the day. Unfortunately, due to the absence of this mode, the game lacks incentive to play the next level. Because I don't have that sense of progressing a campaign to eventually control this land, playing the next level inevitably begins to feel like a grind. Additionally, without this incentive, the low mission variety begins to tax even more, since most missions boil down to beat up the enemies, literally in terms of mission objective. If you enjoy slaughtering hordes of foes this is alleviated, but still an issue none the less. 

Despite all this, I would still recommend this game, at least to certain people. I would say that, in general, one piece fans will enjoy this game, and warriors fans may like it for the new abilities mechanics. Honestly, a conquest type mode would make this game perfect and I would pay for dlc to add that. Regardless, this game will still be my go to for a quick one piece fix. 

If you read this far, thanks for hearing me out and lets hope bandai adds more than just chars.

PW4 is a fun musou game crippled by a couple bizarre design flaws. It has engaging combat and does a good job at making its diverse cast feel very distinct from one another, but lacks long term replayability because there is no incentive to grind, or mechanism to track grinding.

Due to how grades are set permanently at the first stage clear, there's no incentive to re-do stages on different characters and difficulties to grind for the S. And due to how character progression works, you can power a character up all the way without having played them at all. These design flaws make the content in the game feel even more limited, and work against its strength of character diversity. 

It's unfortunate that Bandai neglected to at least give us a statistics page where we could see our kills etc by character; that alone would go a long way towards making it feel like you're accomplishing something when clearing stages you've already completed. As it is, it feels like the game wants me to stop playing after I've finished all the content once. DLC characters seem cool but don't address this issue or add any replayability. 

Still, it's at least 40 hours of solid fun and the combat really is well done. It could have been great, but it's still good. Highly recommended for One Piece fans.

An incredible game if you're a fan of One Piece or Dynasty Warriors. Some of the characters are really fun to play and feel powerful as they mow down hundreds of enemies. The skill tree is a nice touch and it's engaging to unlock things as you progress.

HOWEVER, the UI is horrible and it takes up like 70% of the screen in an already hectic game with tons of effects and camera shakes. There's a constant message system that tells you the stage progress and it's pretty much on screen at all times.

The game also makes some enemies feel like HP sponges. It's not as big of a deal as past entries since there are at least some size variances and special fights that mix things up here and there, but it can get tedious.

Honestly, the UI is the only thing that really sucks about this game. Other than that, it might be one of the best One Piece games out there.

Playing this as I read and catch up, I was somewhere back in Dressrosa when I stopped reading, so I'm working towards it but slowly. Currently at the very start of Wano.

The combat feels improved generally, particularly when you get a strong enemy into a midair juggle and then pin them back onto the ground.

This game eschews leveling for what is effectively just skill trees but divvies them up with character coins, which you get through general gameplay but also through progress, so there is a natural rhythm to powering up characters where you'll unlock some, fight, and unlock a little more.

The only level is a crew rank which characters get just by attending battles, so your characters will at least build potential side by side, and if you want to level up one particular character you don't have to play AS them in order to do it. I think it's a well designed reinterpretation of Warriors leveling.

I like the cutscenes, they are mostly fairly static but the characters remain as expressive as they are in the manga and anime. Some cutscenes are changed to accommodate for the fact they don't have character models or voice actors for everyone, which is fair enough, but it feels as faithful as it can get while doing so. A lot of content from previous games is skipped so I think this pairs particularly well with 3 which is a lot more detailed about each arc in the series (PS4 version is probably best, pc is a bit broken, though definitely worth it if it's your only option.)

One particular thing I like is how skills work, you can shuffle around 4 skills on a character, and they can be attacks, effect applications, form changes, whatever. Not a lot of them have wowed me so far

A fun and exciting way to relive some of One Piece's greatest storylines. Would highly recommend to fans of the series.

EDIT: So I've just finished the dramatic log and unlocked most of the characters, but I'd say my earlier review still stands. Warriors games aren't everyone's cup of tea, but if you enjoy them or even think you can enjoy them; then this game is for you.
NICE GAME

Does you like one piece? Warriors game? Yes x2? Good game here. No to either, maybe not for you, but if yes to one could still be enjoyable.
Very abbreviated story, especially with the earlier arcs, compared to Pirate Warriors 3 so if you're looking for a primer on One Piece, this ain't it. It's a decent refresher though, hits the major points so far.
Having now finished the game I've got some more thoughts. The games story isn't very good. PW3 is a much better recap of One Piece, this games basically has Dressrosa and Whole Cake arcs, and even those feel rushed through.
Now the gameplay is good, I enjoy it very much and don't think I could go back to PW3 after playing this. However the roster is kinda disappointing. They get all the major characters in, a few are missing that were in PW3, and they added some of course. But overall, it feels a bit lackluster.
What's there is good, I like every character I've played as, and I haven't played as them all so maybe I'm just being super spoiled, but I feel like there's characters missing.
Anyway, despite these negatives my thoughts are still pretty positive, though I think I played more PW3 than I will 4, mainly cause I was achievement hunting and the achievements here are quite nice, 3's were very grindy.

If you are buying this to play local multiplayer just forget about it.
I have tried for hours to make it work with 2 controllers but the game simply does not recognize the second one. Some people claim that it works but I'm sceptical considering everything I have tried.
Buy it on console instead.

[h1] Recommended for anyone who's into One Piece [/h1]

This is a fun and straightforward musou game with a good amount of playable characters. Graphics are very nice for conveying the anime artstyle, nothing like the abomination that is Jump Force. The game has three primary game modes and I haven't even gone through the first one yet which is the main story. The game's just so fun that I felt I had to drop a review already. 

But it's only really worth it if you're a fan of One Piece. This game does go through the storyline events but in an extremely condensed manner. It skips over entire arcs like East Blue, Skypiea, Thriller Bark, Impel Down, Fishman Island and Punk Hazard on top of only showing the bare minimum of what happened during the arcs that it does cover. So unless you've read the manga or seen the anime, you'll have no idea what is happening and who the characters are. 

Cutscenes are also in 30fps so they look hideously out of place and choppy. A lot of the story content that has you going through dialogue boxes just looks very flat and emotionless. 

Personal score: 8/10

I played this on the switch when it first came out, I don't remember a whole lot about how it played, but being new to PC gaming I thought i'd give it another go. On top of the thoughts I already had about this, being that the story only covers 6 of the story arcs, there is next to no reason to replay any of the missions aside from S rank, the awful levelling system and the lack of characters which to be honest, the DLC did kind of make up for, this game for me also could not play without major lag even at the lowest of settings, looked absolutely terrible and there was no option in the settings menu that could do anything to make this even the tiniest bit less unenjoyable. Probably the only good thing about this game is the already existing soundtrack, most of which is carried over from pre-installments of the series.
If you're looking for a One Piece game to play, just buy Pirate Warriors 3, it's honestly so much better in so many ways.

Alright so i've completed the story and i've finished the treasure log plus all achievements. These are my thoughts on the game.

The visuals are a huge stepup from oppw3, the game looks amazing in terms of gameplay. However the cutscenes are just really awkward looking. One piece just does not transfer well into 3d. Atleast the animators don't put enough effort into the cutscenes in order for them to look somewhat good. 

The combat is cool, characters now have the ability to do aerial combos, expanding everyone's moveset from oppw3. However actually performing combos on any major enemy is a nightmare. You'd think that when you successfully stun an enemy you'd be able to perform a combo on them right? No, they produce a red aoe that stuns you wether they're midair or being hit. Then they go into their full force burst and if you're fighting any type of logia then have fun because they're going to be impervious to all damage despite you being in full force burst yourself or not. Additionally you can't continue your combo after dashing like you could in oppw3, in this game dash has a hitbox which is just awkward when you try to combo. It was nicer before when you could do half your combo, dash, then do the rest after the dash.

If you bought this game looking forward to playing as characters like Kaido then don't. Kaido is extremely linear when it comes to his standard form moveset. Due to the wano arc being like 4-5 episodes in when they made this game they didn't have any clue what to do with Kaido since he has only used about 2 moves in the anime at the time. In the game Kaido launches rocks, yells and belly flops. His dragon form is cool but it's EXTREMELY awkward trying to combo anyone with it due to how big he is. However Whitebeard was well done in this game. Way more fun to play than in oppw3 and he's even bigger this time around.

The story is a huge letdown from oppw3, while oppw3 was made before dressrosa finished they had to improvise on how to end the arc. They went with the "power of friendship" path in that game which was cringe. In this game it's the exact same, the later half of wano is a huge letdown since they just bring back all previous characters into wano for no reason at all because they have no reason what to do with the story. They don't even feature important characters like Tama in the story which is one of Luffy's main driving forces to actually fight Kaido. In my opinion they should've released the game after wano is finished or just not include an unfinished arc in the story. 

Speaking of arcs, They skipped the entire East Blue storyline and the first mission starts directly in Alabasta, they skip a bunch of arcs for no apparent reason making the story feel very clunked up together. 

If you want to play this for the co-op then I don't recommend it. The online might as well not exist. When i bought this game i got it because one of my friends also bought it so i wanted to play together with him. I expected us to be able to do combos together and use teamwork to our advantage, turns out that online  is extremely desynced when it comes to fighting any enemy that isn't a minion. 

In conclusion this game was a letdown for me, takes like 30 hours of gameplay to complete the story and about another 30 to complete the treasure log stories, which is just more improvised cringy storylines. Not worth 50 euros
This was an awesome game, the orginal Wano ark was the best. The unlockable characters are really awesome to play with.

(Edit: I highly suggest you read the WHOLE review before judging off of recommended.)
great game, dialogue scenes look kinda ugly but gameplay is really nice, fun and addicting.

Edit after another 20 hours: The game is really good if you only consider the gameplay. I assume only one piece fans will consider this but I want to highlight that you should ONLY consider purchasing if you have watched/read One Piece. Originally I said the dialogue scenes look kinda ugly, this is still true but they are also executed worse as you progress through the game. Iconic quotes are changed, 5 minute scenes are rushed into 2 seconds, characters no longer exist (resulting in scenes being changed like Flampe's needle being shot by a chess guard or the scene not existing at all - King Riku is not in this game, so looking back Dressrosa has a very vague ending.)
To contrast from this, considering the gameplay itself I've really enjoyed this. This is potentially my favourite Hack & Slash game.

Edit after finishing Wano arc: It had a nice start but goes downhill. It was really interesting to play through the arc at the start due to it being non canon and not knowing what will happen, and the start does bring some hype with returning characters. However it feels rushed, short and doesn't feel that much thought has been put into it. This arc is joint shortest levels of any arc along with Alabasta for 5 levels, with the remaining few arcs having 6 (Enies, Marineford, Saboady) and WCI having 7. Mid arc feels repetitive and confusing, the levels end up just being fight the same Kaido/Big Mam pirates over and over until the final boss fight (which was a walk in the park, he didn't really attack you at all.) This leaves an unsatisfying ending, where Wano is free but no luxurious celebration occurs, just a normal, generic banquet outdoors. Alongside this, the ending does not feel amazing as the only Kozuki present are Momonuske and Kinemon.

I currently have this remaining at reccomended as throughout the game, majorly the gameplay has been amazing and given me the most joy out of a Hack and Slash game. However, this recommendation depends on if you are willing to only judge the game through its gameplay and if the game is on a large sale (I picked this up for about £15.99, no more should be payed.)

One Piece: Pirate Warriors 4 improves over its sequel with some key combat refinements that make the core '1vX' combat loop more addictive than ever.

+ Increased mobility

+ Aerial Combat

+ Variety in special moves and ability to bring up to 4 simultaneously in battle

+ Greater sense of scale with "Giant" characters and destructible environments

+ Massive roster

- Re-used cutscenes

- Story quality hasn't improved despite a new generation and a smaller quantity of covered storylines

- Tons of mid combat notifications that are annoying and can't be disabled

I quiet enjoyed the last One Piece Warriors game and this one is proving just as fun. The changes they made have been interesting and some are good and others not so much in my own opinion. I've currently only cleared Alabasta area so far, so I dont know if you can swap allies mid combat later or not. But I don miss that feature. Changes I liked though was the ability wheel that you can use to change out skills as well as the character maps that you can use the coins you get to upgrade your group overall or focus on a character.  Providing the bigger enemies with shields definitely provides some extra difficulty but not much that it made me want to swap from normal mode. 

So my final thoughts are that this game is fun for people who like smashing large groups of enemies and looking awesome while doing it!

These are just my personal thought about the game.
Likes:
- They upgrading (or reworking?) aerial battle works much better than i thought, especially for Speed and Sky type character. It makes the combat much faster, feels like a dbz fight when you juggle and move the enemy around with those aerial combos. And the aerial fight actually suits the character like Sanji, Marco, Vinsmokes brother, Crocodile, etc
- Giant unit are hella fun. They felt so strong and can clear those higher difficulty mission easier. The destructible environment also helps in making them feels more powerful
- The new upgrade and skill system also feels nice. Help yourself by not watching the moveset from Youtube. It is part of the fun to wonder what kind of move you can unlock from the skill map.
- The cutscene looks clean, you can feel the upgrade from Pirate Warrior 3

Dislikes:
- Half of the new unit are locked behind DLC. You can get vinsmoke brothers and sisters, kaido, bigmom, katakuri, carrot, kidd with the basegame. But other supernovas, sweet commanders, wano characters are locked behind dlcs (which i don't really mind buying when discount)
- No costume for wholecake island nami, despite her being a big contributor in the arc. And in general, the costume just seems lacking
- Wholecake island is supposed to be the new big arc that they can implement fully following the anime since Pirate Warrior 3, but the execution seems a bit lackluster. No Crackers fight, no Smoothies, no Djinn dude. I'm not demanding them to be playable, but they definitely need to shows at least as enemies
- The campaign starts from pre-timeskip as far as Arabasta arc, which i think won't be needed anymore. Yes Arabasta and Ennies Lobby arc is really cool, but we have saved vivi and robin in the previous game (which also more fleshed out). There's no point in doing that again, and should just focused on making new world stuff better.


Final verdict:
- The progress for character feels fun, the new mechanic (aerial combos and giant unit) are hella fun, and makes it different from previous game. Definitely worth buying it.
- Don't pirate it since it unlocks everything iirc, which takes half of the fun away
- The issue mentioned in "Dislike" is quite annoying. So for best value, just buy it when discount (but when it's in discount, go buy the DLC. I think the DLC characters are fun and the price is actually justified)

This is an enjoyable hack and slash action game in the vein of Dynasty Warriors - Your hero will take on massive crowds of enemies and tackle thematic objectives around a map, often with wildly changing objectives throughout a particular mission. 

The One Piece series is represented well here. The characters look and sound incredible. Their move sets are hilarious and true to their presentation in the anime more or less. In this game you will play through the following arcs: Arabasta, Enies Lobby, Marineford (just the battle, not the prison breakout), Dressrosa (Really just the birdcage, the colosseum is minimized, and a missed opportunity), Whole Cake Island, and Wano Country. Arcs inbetween and around those played through are covered in a voice over montage between Islands. 

There are a wide array of characters and costumes for the characters to spice up your visuals and play styles. The advancement for the characters and their abilities is rewarding and fun, I can see it being a bit grindy towards the end. 

The music in the game is... 'fine'. With so much amazing music from the show, there are just a lot of missed opportunities to incorporate it here. The additional music pack that they are selling for $17-$20 USD is absurd, and it should be included. I read some reviews where that music had some issues as well, but they appear to have been resolved (the music didn't loop, it does now)

So, I recommend this game with a caveat: You really need enjoy the game play of the Dynasty Warriors games and One Piece to get value here.  It captures the madcap and wild adventures of the One Piece crew, and the massive crowd battles really seem to fit - The "Deluxe" edition simply includes all of the character DLC packs, so if your interest in those characters is low, you can likely skip it for the base game, and be perfectly happy.

I grew up playing Dynasty Warriors and started with Dynasty Warriors 2, and own most of them. I also grew up watching One Piece teasing a friend that Bleach and Naruto would outlast One Piece, boy was I wrong. When I found out One Piece Pirate Warriors 4 was a hack and slash made by Omega Force and Koei the same makers of Dynasty Warriors buying the game was a no brainer. I simply waited for Japan's golden week to start to buy the games deluxe edition at a discounted price and I have no regrets. I've owned the game for less than a week but have already invested 18+ hours in to the game.

Updated Review:

I still highly recommend this game, and anyone who has read my OPPW3 review knows why.  PW4 does an amazing job of taking the mechanics of Warriors games and changing them up to be unique and fun again, with the changes to super moves being the most welcome of the lot. Allowing up to four player selected moves to be available, with form changing and self heals on the list for many characters, is a huge step forward for the genre. The varied maps, changes to the way territory works, and dash gauge all add to the fast paced, frenetic fun of this game. Combine that with an awesome cast, both base and DLC offerings, and you have a solid and fun brawler worth its weight in Beli.

The one, and only gripe I have, is the fact that it cuts so many great arcs out of the story, jumping so far forward in the One Piece timeline and skipping over so many battles and characters that it ends up being only half as long as the janky, busted game that came before it. But if the next installment of the series can somehow merge 4's fast paced and solid mechanics, as well as excellent porting, with 3's sheer depth of content, then PW5 would become the definitive edition of this storied franchise. One can only hope for such an outcome.

Pros
+ Dash Cancels, Air Combos and Big Damage to the Environment
+ Great Character Models
+ Mega-Church of Katakuri Approved
+ Co-op is Solid
+ Big Mom and Kaido are BIG!!!
+ It has that Lego Star Wars vibe of defeating a boss, and then getting to Free Play as them.
+ BIG MONKE LUFFY VS GIANT LIZARD KAIDO is a good final battle for this game.

Cons
- This game skips a few arcs (Skypiea, Fishman Island, pretty much all of East Blue.) It does recap events that aren't playable, and focuses more on the major battles within the series.
- This game is also really quick to beat your first time through, and there isn't much replay value outside of mastering different characters and 
- The Boss Armor is ANNOYING! It only pads out the fight, and can easily break the flow of combat when it recharges. Not as big of an issue in the late game, but by that point it's a grind to surpass.
- Invisible Walls where you think you should be able to jump, and the maps tend to be bigger than needed - especially when a mission-important ally needs help from the other side of the battlefield.
- I miss the Crew Attacks from 3... being able to have the crew line up and unleash a Combination Finisher on the Bosses really hyped-up the fights.

OVERALL
Gameplay - B (Only repetitive if you don't do combos on the plot important enemies. There is a lot of impact with the Supers, but you do have to grind in order to start One Punch styling on enemies. Controls feel good, Camera never fights, but the boss battle armor can get annoying if you aren't learning air combo tech.)
Story - EH (Watch/Read One Piece, this game doesn't flesh out all the characters)
Music - SSS (I highly enjoyed the remix of the returning OST in this game series.)
Graphics - Anime +

BOTTOM LINE
If you are already a fan of One Piece, and enjoy the Warrior-style gameplay... then I recommend giving this installment a try. I still recommend 3 as the starting point of the Pirate Wars series, since 1 and 2 were just full-priced Betas back in the day. For a PROPER One Piece game experience, I still want a game where you sail around and can fully explore islands - needs more inspiration from Black Flag and the Caribbean in KH3, or even P5S!

I waited until I had completed the game's final mission (in its free-play mode) before writing a review, and I can now say without any doubt that this is by far my favourite Pirate Warriors game (and I was extremely fond of the earlier ones).

To get the cons out of the way, it misses out a handful of characters from the earlier games because it does not cover their arcs in the main story mode. Actually, that's the only con I can think of...Oh, actually, the game's final arc, in Wano is fun because it's pretty wacky, but it's not a particularly good story.

But as for pros, it makes up for those missing characters with some 15 or more different ones, which can be SO much fun to play as! It's so satisfying playing as each of Big Mom's Sweet Three, or each of Sanji's brothers (whose play-styles are varied in the game - I may not remember which name belongs to who, but I certainly remember their different moves!) Also, Katukiri is a boss. And each of the Worst Generation. Secondly, and SUPER random, but I thoroughly enjoy the new "jumping" mechanic, and it really does make it feel much more like the One Piece of the manga/anime.

Also, the giants really do FEEL like giants, and they are absolute power-houses in the game: Kaido, Big Mom, Jack, Sengoku and Whitebeard all feel physically imposing when you come up against them in a random match, and their strength corresponds with that, you have to employ a lot more skill when dealing with them.

A lot of people complain about the game not being very "long", but they only seem to be addressing the main storyline. At nearly fifty hours I still haven't even played all of the missions (the main story took me around 18 hours). What is also fun in the main story is that you get to pick very different characters (so not merely the straw hats, but others who were involved in the events, like playing as Ace or Whitebeard at the battle of Marineford), which is a heap of fun. Of course, you get the chance to go back and play every level with anyone you want, but these were especially touching.

With so many characters and such good gameplay, I would strongly recommend the game, whether you like One Piece (or Koei games) or not.

This game changed my world view of the One Piece show and fandom. Putting myself in the shoes of these characters is a truly life-changing experience. Just watching the show or reading the manga can only give you a certain amount of depth to the characters because its simply words on a screen or paper. This game instead opts for expertly crafted cutscenes with beautifully rendered 3D models of the character you love, and lines of dialogue plastered along the bottom of the screen during battle. Battle binds one another and I have now battled with all the One Piece greats. From having played this game, I can proudly say that I UNDERSTAND the motivations of characters such as Big Mom, Kaido, Blackbeard, etc. No medium other than games can give you this truly in depth feeling of connection to a character because no other medium will literally place you in the characters shoes.

In all honesty, it pained me to say characters...
Because after this once in a lifetime experience, I can truly call these P E O P L E Nakama.

All in all a great musou One Piece game I would rate it a 7/10.

One Piece Pirate Warriors 4 is an excellent game for fans of One Piece, and I count myself among that fanbase, but let's set that aside. As a Warriors game, it's pretty good and probably one of the best looking and most streamlined ones I've played. I'll admit, I haven't played a Warriors game in so long, with my personal favorite being Dynasty Warriors 4 with the Extreme Legends expansion pack on the PlayStation 2. But it's good to see this particular genre extending to various franchises, such as One Piece and even Legend of Zelda.

If you're expecting dynamic gameplay, you're looking at the wrong game. However, the monotonous action is GREATLY alleviated by the massive roster of characters! Each one plays completely different than the last, and all have varied combos that keep the combat fresh despite the repetitious fighting. These characters are split into four types: Power, Speed, Technique, and Sky. Power is straightforward, focusing on outward brawling and jumping into the fray with powerful combos. Speed's definitely about dashing about using the "power dash", unleashing quick combos. Technique is quite hard for me to get used to, focusing a lot on abilities that lay traps or inflict status effects, with normal attacks not being as effective as the combos and abilities ( which allow you to bring groups of enemies closer to you ). Sky does what it says on the box, it's all about air combos and flying from enemy to enemy unleashing attacks, with much less focus on ground combos. It's really fun collecting characters, leveling up their strength, and mastering their capabilities. This is a One Piece fan's dream come true, because anyone who's anyone is here! From my personal favorite Trafalgar Law, to complete badass powerhouses such as Whitebeard, you can't go wrong with the roster.

Like any other Warriors game, the gameplay is exactly as you expect. Missions pit different forces against each other in fairly diverse locales, and different events happen to throw variety into the mix. It's repetitive, but cozy and relaxing, with some tense moments. Unlike the Warriors games I'm used to, you can't just defeat every "officer" and suddenly win. There is some level of strategy at play, and it's up to you to choose whether an optional objective is more important or to go rescue an allied officer in trouble. Allied officers can actually win fights, and don't always need babysitting, depending on what mission you play and on what difficulty. This is probably one of the few Warriors games where it feels like you absolutely need everyone in order to win, and you aren't just a powerhouse who can win the entire battle on your own, especially on hard mode where you need every ally you can get. It's a legit challenge, and I'm pleased that it ditched the stupid systems of the past. Dynasty Warriors 4 was so good, but it often felt too easy to win once you closed every reinforcement gate and defeated every single optional officer to lower enemy morale. There is no morale system in Pirate Warriors 4, meaning that victory is about achieving objectives or striking specific targets rather than blowing away every enemy officer.

I'm very impressed with the amount of love and content put into this game. You can tell that the developers love One Piece, including all of the most iconic moments in the "Dramatic Log" story mode which acts as your campaign. I'm often left wondering "WHO THE HELL ARE THESE PEOPLE?!" when I look at these generic pirate armies allied with Luffy and his comrades, but the story does a fantastic job recapping the anime for you without you needing to even watch ( or rewatch ) the dauntingly huge anime. Well, for the most part. Other modes including "Treasure Log", which is a fantastic mode featuring all sorts of fun missions. These missions act as alternate reality "What if THIS happened..." scenarios. They are an excellent way to earn coins ( a fun currency featuring little images on them ) and Berries ( in game currency ) to level up your characters outside of the main Dramatic Log. "Free Log" on the other hand allows you to play any mission with whoever you like, from what I can tell. Dramatic Log is very restrictive with who you can play as per mission, after all.

The amount of content will keep you coming back for more, and wanting to collect everything, including leveling up the quite enjoyable "Growth Map" progression system for each character. There's a Growth Map that powers all characters up, and then there's personal unique Growth Maps for individual characters. This system is fun because each stat, ability, or skill is represented by tiny little islands upon an ocean. I found this a really cute and thematic progression system, with some abilities being more meaningful rather than straight power increases. Such as upgrades that grant new combos, and entirely new skills. I mean, I enjoy straight power increases, but it's sometimes hard to tell when I'm playing on Hard mode! Believe me, that difficulty mode will kick your ass! You're going to need every point of health and attack power you can get!

What else is there to say? Well, I like the music sometimes and it sounds very One Piece, and other times it sounds like royalty free tunes. The voice acting is good if set to Japanese with English subtitles, which is what the game appears to be at by default anyway. Is it me, or is EVERYONE here? And I mean every Japanese voice actor for One Piece? Other than sounds, I wish the combat was more satisfying and chunky, when I slash at my enemies with Zoro it doesn't really sound enough like I'm really CUTTING into some fools. This problem persists for many characters, but luckily it helps that buildings or objects get destroyed in satisfying ways as you rampage around. I'd still say that Dynasty Warriors 4 has the most satisfying combat, with meaty metallic weapon sounds as they land on your enemies. It's a trivial thing, yes, but it often feels like the hits aren't as satisfying as they could be ( in Pirate Warriors 4 ). Maybe it's because they are often overpowered by other sounds, and even the music? As for the visuals, they are pretty good looking for a genre that is often ugly as sin and low fidelity. Unfortunately, you do get plenty of muddy textures, and low polygon details sometimes. But the characters themselves look straight out of the anime, for the most part. I'm not going to complain when the Warriors franchise doesn't deliver good visuals most of the time, I welcome these colorful and decent graphics!

Well, that's all I have to say. If you're a One Piece fan, this game is an absolute must!

Already a big fan of the Warriors style games. If you are in the mood for a beat em up that is surprisingly robust with some minor RPG elements this will be the game for you. The best entry for the Pirate Warrirors IMO

A fun "hack and slash" game, even for non-one piece fans. The game does a great job at making (most) of the characters available feel utterly broken. The campaign feels fairly short, though I suspect it will take longer to complete for someone that's new to the series.

The in-game story only skims through the One Piece story. You will miss out on a lot of detailed plot if you haven't watched the anime.

The game itself is quite easy, especially once you start to fill out your character's map and you become much stronger. In my opinion, the old levelling system in Pirate Warriors 3 felt more rewarding than the levelling map we have now. I especially liked the old level break feature that encouraged players to farm for specific content to reach max level. The system in PW4 is similar, but doesn't have the same kick as actual levels did.

The new Treasure Log has thorough replayability, though it does feel repetitive after a while. I personally preferred the Dream Log from Pirate Warriors 3, with all the different routes to choose from. Almost 30 hours in and I've still got a long way to go before fully completing the game. If you're a completionist, this is the game for you.

A super fun game for One Piece fans. The gameplay is easy to understand and you don't have to memorize long combos. It's really satisfying to beat up hundreds of enemies, and see your favorite characters in action. In the Dramatic Log, there's a chapter for most important arcs. I'm a little bummed that there isn't Punk Hazard though lol. There's also the Treasure Log, which is fun to collect berries and coins from. Characters feel unique from one another, so if one character doesn't fit your play style you can always play from the many other characters that might.
There are some things that make the game frustrating, like the map designs. It's really easy to get lost, and sometimes I find myself running back and forth trying to find where I'm supposed to go. With how spread out your allies can be sometimes, it's hard to run and help them if they're struggling. There's a lot going on at once, which can be hard to manage. Split-screen co-op is really hard to focus on and can be easy to miss sub-missions. You can pause the game to view things like your missions and allies in more detail, but it's really annoying to keep having to pause the game to see what's going on. The pause menu is easy to navigate though, so it's not a huge pain.
Overall though, I would recommend this game to other One Piece fans. It's certainly enjoyable!

This game is an improvement over the previous entry. The graphics of the character models are similar, but they are touched up and more expressive. The new lighting also makes the models and graphics stand out from the previous entry. The environments have been given a big overhaul making them match the environments from the source more closely. Also, the stages are BIG, much larger than I expected given the demo. The game is missing some arcs but for the story content they do have its far more fleshed out than in the previous game, with more scenes and no still images talking to each other. The animations for the scenes and combat are also improved, making it look and feel much more smooth.

The combat has seen an overhaul from the previous games, it feels very similar but fresh. When you first it might feel a bit more limited, and that's because it is, but as you progress and unlock more combos and skills, the depth really starts to shine through. The combo's still flow similar to the previous game, but the unique action skill is gone, replaced with specials that allow you to equip 4 at a time. Heavy combos have also somewhat been replaced with the heavy button now working similar to unique action from the previous game, but still holds its function as a combo extender from light attacks.

The game has also changed the quick dashes from the previous game to a new button and attached a stamina meter to it, allowing you to dash even farther and still use it to extend combos. Now the game includes a jump button and air combos to help further spice up the combat, its a nice welcome and helps it all feel and flow more smooth. 

Overall as a fan of the previous entries and One Piece, I am very satisfied with this game. Some other reviewers have noted issues with running the game. I have not, the game started up just fine for me, plays without problem and detected my controller just fine.

It's a Dynasty Warrior game. You mash "x" and "y" on your controller in combos to mow down hordes of ennemies as one of One Piece main characters. It's great fun trying out the different characters. You don't need to have played through any previous Pirate Warriors games either. While it's possible to play this without having ever watched the anime or read the manga (there are arcs that you play through with a narrator explaining the broad lines) you might be left a bit confused on what's going on and why. If you're neither a fan of One Piece or Dynasty Warriors type of game, this might not be for you.

For fans and newcomers of OP, this game is probably my favorite Warriors off-series game on Steam. As a hack 'n' slash genre contender, OPPW4 has powerful and fun characters with cool combos and VFX, beautiful stages and interesting matchups. The game loosely follows the plot of the manga/anime (loosely = skipping the filler and abridging most of the important events) and adds "what if" scenarios to the mix via another game mode.

Leveling characters can be a bit tedious, because the game's coin system makes you grind more than just a few battles to get the rarest of coins. Money won't be as big of a problem. 

As a musician, I really appreciate the soundtrack. There are nice rock beats, a hint of metal and exceeding amounts of funky flavor in it. It really packs a punch and just makes you listen to it. I've sometimes just stopped fighting to listen to the BGM, it's really good!

Absolutely worth the price! :)

This game gets worse and worse the more you realize how few features and content it has.
While Pirate Warriors 3 was a great musou game with a coat of One Piece on it, Pirate Warriors 4 is a OP fandom jerk off with a mediocre musou game attached. The same OP fans that will celebrate not having lesser characters in the game but will suck Oda's balls after expending three whole chapters in some tertiary character's flashback.

First problem is the garbage story mode it has. PW4 has chapters focusing on an arc with several levels dedicated to it, it sounds good on paper but the levels are pitifully short (In the Alabasta arc two of those levels were 1v1 with Crocodile), lack unlockables, side challenges, etc.
PW3 had one major arena level condensing an arc; they were big, challenging and with a lot of side stuff in them. Not to mention PW3 had one of those arena levels for every arc (up to date). PW4 doesn't even acknowledges East Blue, Skypea and many other things.
Just to put it into perspective Alabasta was 5% of the content in PW3 and 20% of PW4 story mode.
Character models and graphics don't look that much better than PW3 and while the level assets look better they are reused a lot more as well.
Some levels drag on and on making you do the same thing over and over. The Shabondy level for example consists of dozens of minutes of fighting pacifistas over and over. It also features an optional fight with Kizaru; wich in PW3 was challenging and unlocked special items when beaten, here it just gives you a message saying "Kizaru has recovered, please run away".
Lastly, they ignored huge chunks of the actual series and instead put a lot of effort into that garbage fanfiction at the end. Wich of course has to include every character ever conceived by the series and turns out it has all been some Kurohige's plot, just like PW3's Dressrosa (except there it was only 5% of the whole story mode). Nobody cares about that, go to deviant art if you're so eager to write trash; your fanfictions suck. I can't stress enough how cringe inducing this fanfiction is. It's cute that they think they can write because they add little cutscenes every five minutes as if this garbage has any value. 

Tea party from hell! has to be the worst designed level in history, i'm convinced nobody tested it properly. You have to constantly deal with Katakuri wich can basically kill you in two hits (more proof this whole thing is just to jerk off OP fans) and it shows how bad the targeting system is; "oh, did you want to lock on the hyper powerful gary stu that's murdering you? not the generic soldier next to it?" The only way i found to beat it was using Brook's broken healing skill (i'm playing on hard though, so maybe it's not shit in lesser difficulties?).
Levels are horribly designed in general with a lot of cliffs and ramps where half of the time you can jump/drop from and half the time have force walls. It's specially annoying since enemies are blown away after every combo team rocket style completely breaking the pace of the combat, you can chain it a bit but the game has some stupid stamina mechanic for that as well; I guess for the desperate souls that want some online balance in this dumpster fire?
Another issue are the stupid npcs. A lot of missions require certain npcs to reach an area but they just get stuck watching the fucking scenery while you have to fight extremely powerful enemies that revive after a minute! And keep in mind that is the only real different objective other than beat X and is not even properly working?
You can notice how much they cared about fanservice during the Katakuri fight. Instead of simply giving you a new tool (Snakeman) and letting you figure the boss, they interrupt the fight with power ups and cutscenes to make it accurate to the series! Who the fuck cares! You do understand that people buying this already watched the series right? That fight is shit from the start, Katakuri does so much damage that it's ridiculous and the power ups seem to show whenever they want. Maybe they are expecting you to dodge as if you were playing Dark Souls or something but instead of understandable patterns you have to deal with random cum shots from the floor and attacks that can hit you from the other side of the map at bullet speed.

Next issue are the ginormous characters. Sure they are more accurate to the size they have in the series (wich in itself tends to be quite inconsistent) but for fuck sake there's a reason why PW3 kept them around the same scale! You end up so away from the action that becomes really dull, everything you fight is just a miniature figurine with no characteristics. Jesus christ create a fun game instead of pandering to OP fans!
When fighting against giant characters your biggest enemy is the camera (ironically), it has no clue what to do. It doesn't keep your character in frame, gets stucked against walls and that's when your character isn't stuck inside the giant enemy model. At this point i'm just wondering why couldn't they just use the same fucking game as before and improve a lot of stuff (unless they did, in wich case kudos on how much effort you required to fuck it up).
And you think characters will behave different when fighting a giant character or a miniature one? Of course not, giant character will swing their weapons in the air and the small playmobile enemies will get hit anyway, all giant characters are is a bag with more hit points and a bigger hit box.

Another thing is the character types. In paper sounds good, assign each character a different type (power, speed, sky, etc) but what ends up happening is that characters of a similar type end up feeling similar. In PW3 each character was unique and the lack of customization forced you to adapt to that character (wich made them more varied and fun to experiment with) while here since you can customize everything, characters become really bland and samey to play as (in a game that's already quite repetitive).
Sky characters are specially stupid since they hover above everyone when powered up wich makes your skills and attacks miss enemies half the time (and you're crazy if you think enemies won't be able to hit you during that time).
Let me tell you about the special skills, they are as everything else fucked. There's some sort of classification for them i guess; well there's different types of icons at least but they don't mean anything as far as i could tell. Half of the time they can't kill even the simplest enemies. Worst, since even the most basic elite has a shield and they can stagger you, most of the time your skill gets canceled and can't even repel the enemies a bit.

The shield mechanic is pure garbage, nothing more to add to that.
 
There's too much character moments from the series inserted as cutscenes instead of just giving the story basics, wich makes no sense. Think about it, if you're a OP fan you wouldn't care about the story bits (you've probably already read the manga, watch the anime, seen youtube shorts, etc) but how the story is adapted to this type of game. Meanwhile if you're a musou fan you couldn't follow the story because it's completely disjointed!
Let me tell you, the cutscenes in this game are so stupid and cringe inducing, it's One Piece as interpreted by the head injury ward patients. Why they waste so much time and money in those is ridiculous.

Here's a gripe i have with both entries. If you already have a lot of characters modeled, voiced and mechanically sound enough to be fighting against, why not go the extra mile and make them playable!? There has to be around 100+ characters in the game and only around half of them playable, it's dumb.

In conclusion if you want a good musou go and play Pirate Warriors 3, otherwise go and play Senran Kagura for a mediocre musou with more fanservice (considering the state of One Piece is around the same level).

One Piece is one of my top favourite animes. When I first saw this game, I was so excited, and even playing it made me remember all the great moments through the arcs, and bringing back memories. Too bad they didn't include all the arcs. I would of loved to play the east blue arc, as well as skypea and all the other ones. But they did include really good arcs too, even the original wano arc made up by them. One problem I have with the game is, that there isn't a big selection of costumes. The pre time skip nami, chopper, robin, and franky characters aren't playable, just the post time skip. Those aren't really a big problem, but still something I always think about. The rest of the game feels really nice, and is very much playable. In the first 2 days, I have spent 20 hrs on this game, which is quite something, cause not many games can grab my attention right away. I love all the characters, and their abilities are just like in the anime. Which makes me happy. Some more characters could of been added though. For example, to just name a few. Garp, Sengoku, Kawamatsu, Sandersonia, Marigold, Dogstorm, Cat Viper, Pedro, Enel, Caesar, and probably many more. But I am very content with the current characters. Overall I would say that, if you really like one piece, and you want to play the major characters and feel like you are them. Then you should get this game. It's worth every penny, and I will guarantee that any one piece fan would love this game.

Eh short but sweet review. Definitely a fun game to pick up if your a big onepiece fan. Although personally I wouldn't get it unless it were on discount. Now don't get me wrong it's a great game. It feels nice it looks and sounds nice. However in terms of content there isn't really much there besides grinding maps. (Which is upgrading characters.) Granted getting new characters tossed in now and then is great however that being said it still severly lacks content. No new maps, no new scenarios, Nothing. Once you beat story mode and treasure voyage. That's it game is over there is nothing else but the grind.

 Playing with a friend however can help make it a little less repetitive. I've had some funny moments. "Oh man! Kaido just got straight up slapped down by Ussop!" . They really need to add new content at some point or else it's just going to get boring and repetitive and people are going to leave. Granted as an enormus onepiece fan as well as dynasty warriors and warriors orochi I love this type of game so I would never leave.

Edit: After seeing all the dlc coming out. Still hoping for a Mink Themed DLC. Inuarashi, Nekomamushi, pedro. Hype is real.

I hope they add more maps and scenarios soon. The game is MASSIVELY to short. So in recap. Do I recomend this game? Absolutely! Do I recomend the game full price of 60$ Absolutely, NOT! It is not worth 60 at all. Any more then 30$ is pushing it quite a bit.

Improves over its predecessor in many ways but kills already existing stuff in the way. 

The addition of aerial combat and verticality to the different maps makes combat much more interesting. Apart from that, gameplay is not so different from PW3. 

Too many arcs have been eliminated, the game starts at alabasta, skips skypiea, water 7, thriller bark, punk hazard... It breaks the story apart. More work has been put into the features arcs though. PW3 is way better if you want to relive most of the story, but still there is no one piece game that goes as far as DBZ:Kakarot for example (the story is not nearly as big in DBZ though). 

Online is nonexistent, if you have a friend to play then cool, else consider it a single player game. I literally could only play once thanks to a stroke of luck (I guess absence of players...). 

No new game modes have been added, you could consider it a refresh of PW3.
Summarizing, gameplay is really nice, the featured arcs are worked on and graphics/sound have stepped up from the previous game. If you liked PW3 or have a friend to play with, go for it!

The game itself is definitely good, there's no question there if the general type of game is something you like. The only problem is there's a lack of things to do once you get through all of the mission-type activities after the main story is finished. I keep opening the game to play it more/again but the repetitiveness has made me approach the game less and less at this point. Rather than character packs, they should give new modes/challenges.

That said, for me to play through everything and still want more of the game definitely means the game itself was enjoyable and worth the money.

This game, this game, my friend, is perfect (or almost)
I waited 5 years to see this beauty reach the level it is now, just magnificent. Wonderful graphics, updated and more fun gameplay, giant maps and more minions compared to the third game. The game is simply sensational and I could not disagree with that, but of course not everything is perfect unfortunately, the few things I would have to complain about in the 4 game in the franchise are minimal things that in my opinion are simply laziness of the developers. To have taken away arcs, characters, not have added more npcs as bosses (seriously you only put Diamante and Pica as the members of the donquixote family).
A giant map like that and you don’t put the complete donquixote family, you don’t put Daifuku and Oven as bosses on Wholecake Island, I could mention several npcs that you could have added to this game, you could have added. Another fact that also upset me with this game (and that disappointed me so much because it was a simple thing to do as something unnecessary to have removed) is the fact that they took off various costumes from the characters, akainu without his new world costume (he had in the third game, no need to remove) I expected to update this costume and bring his scars and his white navy costume. Kizaru's new world costume (which he also had in the third game), did not update the new world smoker costume for his navy coat (seriously he doesn't even look like a vice admiral without that, they put it on the World Seeker, why not put it on Also here).
And several other characters who had their costumes removed or had no new costumes added relevant to the arcs they were on, aside from that part that left me down, the main problem was that the game was very fast, fast to finish the Dramatic Log, Free Log and Treasure Log, compared to the third game it sins a lot, there is a lack of content in this fourth game, I have 113 hours of PW3 and I didn't even reach 20% of the Nightmare Log, and in less than 80 hours I finished 100% of everything related to the current content of that game, I hope they add more content, because otherwise this game will die easy and fast. Love This Game.

This game can make you waste a lot of hours (in a good way) by being so addictive, especially if you're a fan of One Piece. The game is just like any other Warriors game with the typical wave of enemies that you have to beat, so it can be slightly repetitive in that nature, but if you're a fan of that genre then you have nothing to worry about. 

This game does skip a few arcs throughout the series of One Piece, so certain characters aren't in it, and there's only 7 arcs that get played in this game with a couple being tied together. However if you've played any of the other Pirate Warriors games then you'll already be expecting that. Also it comes with it's own original ending to the game since the current arc they are on isn't finished yet.

TL; DR: This game is awesome and if you're a fan of either One Piece or the Warriors game series then you should pick this up! I hope they make a Pirate Warriors 5 game too!

So let's see, I'm a big fan of the Pirate warriors games, now I hold pirate warriors 3 up on a pedestal as the greatest warriors style game out there, nice amount of characters, they were balanced, the levels were also balanced for K.O and time and the like, it played well, it was just all around great but what about 4 dood?

So 4 is super fun and has some great ideas, sadly those ideas in a weird way ended up being a step backwards, especially for the hardest stuff, okay so for starters the balance has been broken once again, some characters are just too good to use while others not so much, even with the new special attack system where you can press R1 and one of the space buttons for a special attack there are some moves that are just poor, especially with how the new system works for battle, you see all "enemies" have super armour now, it can be broken but until it does they are free to interrupt your attacks at their leisure, this becomes a major issue on harder fights in the treasure log and can even be a hassle normally as the damage at times even when decently levelled up is rather high and health drops are extremely low, this can be mitigated...at the cost of attack as there are skills that allow you to heal over time that you can equip but they take two whole slots, it's a give and take situation where your time score if that's important to you is going to suffer, the old system had some invulnerability going on for characters who powered up but that was at least temporary and only happened once, here it can happen multiple times not only allowing for them to recover their meter but gaining an insane defence boost making for some fights to be more of a chore than fun dood.

next is power up types, there are more than a few which are honestly poor, so here we'll cover the four base types, Power, speed, Sky and purple...because I can't remember what it was actually called XD still power, speed and purple are great, they all have their perks, boosted speed, seemingly a damage boost too but sky? sky is a cool concept but suffers because it makes it harder to hit...well anyone, especially boss types, it even has the flaw of the fact that it takes you a while to fall because you can be pretty high up, it also took away from Sanji's original fighting style that was pretty awesome in 3 that allowed you to basically jump to the opponents you hit with an R2 I believe it was near instantly and then there are forms, Luffy get's a certain power up form that you see on the very first stage you'll play for reasons and it's a massive degrade, besides the fact it's sky it doesn't get the speed boost and if there is a damage boost it's hampered by the attacks being frankly poor dood.

The game world is vast, the levels are nice and long and generally varied and interesting, certainly fun to play in, the soundtrack has some classics from older games, some music from the anime and some new tracks of it's own which are all real, it's fun to play in but it also makes some maps hard to read and traverse dood.

So what do I think? I think it's a stellar game even if it isn't as good as it's predecessor, it has it's annoyances but nothing bad enough that you will regret buying the game by any means, rank doesn't really matter as far as I know either outside of showing off to...I guess your friends IRL? so you can feel free to take your time playing how you want really, the fighting styles are all varied and interesting as is typical of one piece and it's just a fun time, thanks for reading and if you buy it I hope you enjoy dood ^-^
