"Tear It Down! The Tea Party from Hell!" is literally the worst level in any video game. There's no territories you can capture which defeats the point of a musou game. There's 4 enemies, Katakuri, Perospero, Chess Officer, and Chess Soldier. The Chess Officers infinitely respawn until you kill Perospero twice which the game doesn't tell you about. The Chess Soldiers infinitely spawn no matter what cause you can't capture any territory. Most of the mission is fighting Katakuri with a character that has a heal super and hoping one of his supers doesn't hit you cause he constantly has all of his supers charged and if he hits you with one you have to charge your heal super by farming the infinitely respawning enemies. You do this for like an hour on hard mode and a half hour on normal mode only to get hit by Katakuri's command grab super and instant-killed. No one even fights Katakuri in this part of the manga or anime it's completely unnecessary. And if you look up a guide on how to beat the level they all just tell you if you get Brook and Jinbei to the end fast enough you can skip the Katakuri fight but in Hard mode you won't be able to do that because the enemies have too much HP because they can't program a decent enough AI in this game to make it strategically harder instead of just taking more time. So on Hard mode its impossible to get them to the ending before Katakuri blocks it especially when they made Katakuri the strongest character in the game to sell more copies cause of all the Katakuri fan boys. I don't even want to imagine what this level is like on Super Hard Mode it literally ruins the entire game it's the worst experience I've ever had in a video game.

Very typical Warriors game play. Only really get if you are a huge One Piece fan. All characters do feel very different in the way they fight plus some of the interactions between characters are amazing (Perospero + Ivankov is my favorite). Wouldn't really recommend buying at full price but worth picking up on a sale.

Overall this is one of the best One Piece games available right now. However, be warned if you want this game for the story of One Piece prepare for a severe cut in content compared to Pirate Warriors 3 and If you want to buy the game for this I do not recommend it for you. Buy pw3 instead.

I personally did not look forward to and purchase the game for the number of story arcs included but for the new characters, new gameplay mechanics, updated maps, online game modes and future characters. For the most part it delivered on these expectations.

The new mechanics work great for a lot of characters however, some characters do not have any aerial combos.Any character you choose has a decent moveset of combos and special attacks which only expand once you upgrade that character with higher input combos, new special attacks with some characters gaining a form change which completely changes their moveset and attacks dependant on the character you choose.

The character roster overall is an improvement compared to pw3, however certain character's were cut for more questionable choices such as all of Sanji's siblings which all have similar gameplay. Otherwise there are more characters to choose compared to pw3 and they is far more variety between characters in pw4. Each is so unique in how you can play with them.

The maps are overall a nice visual enhancement, however, they are more confusing at times in tight spaces with the larger characters and take some time to learn to navigate. The online mode works ok, but doesn't have great compatibility with each player as you will have to join each other's game every time you want to start a new mission rather than make a party and be able to stay in it like every other online game has. With the gamemodes they are ok, however, Bandai has gone pretty basic with their approach to it. The boss battles are fun only if you have the difficulty maxed out on extreme diffifculty (which is only available after you complete the story) and on the higher levels, when enemy's have higher amounts of health and attack more often.

The problem I had the most with pw3 is that it takes soo long to get access to the higher level combos and abilites of characters no matter how great or trival they are between characters. pw4 solves this for the most part, however, gameplay is different in a good or bad way for some. Main enemies now have an armour you have to break before you can actually start damaging the enemy. In the early game this is fairly annoying and the animations of massive white circles forming gets in the way for seeing the enemy which makes it harder to fight them rather than easier which was the developer's intentions. They did not think this through well, the sounds everytime you hit would have been more than enough. Now in the later sections of the game when your characters are a lot stronger this does benefit this gameplay as fights last longer than in pw3 and you actually feel like you are battling the character's in the world on the higher difficulites compared to pirate warriors 3 which I felt was too short with the 1v1 battles at times. However, this can get more overwhelming to deal with compared to 3 if you are not good enough on the higher difficilities. Pretty good changes overall though for the gameplay and obtaining new abilites for you characters. Be warned Bandai has left some characters wanting with the new mechanics like air combos and form changes especially were left out for a lot of characters such as Chopper and Carrot which would have benfitted immensely from a form change.

Overall if you are looking for a good One Piece beat em up game and a different kind of Pirate Warriors game, I recommend this game with a new roster it keeps things interesting for many hours and more characters for the future will be in the character pass even if it is likely way overpriced for what we will get like Cracker, Smoothie, Judge so far and potentially the Beast Pirates like X-Drake if the scans I have seen are correct.
Dynasty warrior game with one piece characters. Pretty good for a big one piece fan who also likes destroying large groups of enemies with ease.

EDITED: After a few comments in this review, I will add a few points that I didn’t mention before, making it more complete (I will also correct a few grammar mistakes that I made).

Is this a good game? Yes!
Is it better than One Piece Pirate Warriors 3?? Absolutely no!
Is it worth it? Even if you are a One Piece fan, I have my doubts

Pirate Warriors 4 has a few positive aspects over PW3. Better graphics, new characters, the possibility to choose from several skills/moves and a few more (and new) missions. But that's it. Nothing more!

There are ONLY SIX arcs ([spoiler]Alabasta arc, the Enies Lobby arc, the Marineford arc, the New World Saga arc, the Whole Cake Island arc, and a game exclusive Wano arc. The Sabaody Archipelago arc is included in the Marineford arc, and Dressrosa arc is included in the New World Saga arc[/spoiler]).  Bandai had just ONE job: explore the Yonko saga. They didn't even manage to do it properly. There is no Zou Arc. There is no Reverie Arc. The lack of the old arcs and the poorly explored Yonko Saga disappointed me. The only thing new in here is the Whole Cake Island Arc and a poorly made Wano Country Arc.
They separated those 6 arcs in different missions. 5 of those missions are an easy 1x1 fight. Bandai should've put them inside a long mission, e.g. a final boss battle, like they did in PW3. Bandai chose to have more cutscenes (explaining 2/3 of the anime that weren't in the game) and less gameplay. Bandai randomly chose a few arcs to make them playable and the rest (the most part of the anime) to be cutscenes.
It took me a long time to get along with the combat camera. I just didn't like it. 
There are a few situations where you will experience a few bugs (Usopp's barrels don't stay in stairs, ally stuck inside a destroyed building for a long time, ranged characters have trouble to attack enemies that are on different heights, one of Luffy’s air attack send you flying above buildings, missing everything, etc.). There is also a bug where an enemy stay stuck above you (when you are close to the wall or the edge of the map) with a “falling animation”, even if you aren’t doing anything. You can attack it for free for a long time.
THERE IS NO DREAM LOG!! PW3 story mode was incredible. It was very exciting to remember the whole anime. But after getting an S on all missions, you could still have a lot of fun in Dream Log. Too bad, no dream log in here.
Besides that, there is not a single reason for getting an S-rank on all missions (and to complete the gallery) in PW4. You don’t get any reward, any achievement, nothing! The new mission rank system is completely useless.
"New characters". Nice, right? F* no!!!! Why will I want to play with all Sanji's brothers?? Where is Moria? Perona? Eneru? Garp? Kuma?!? ([spoiler] In PW4 you battle against Garp and Kuma but you can't play with them. [/spoiler]).
Don’t get me wrong. It was funny playing with some new characters. The thing I hated the most was the lack of characters that you could play with in PW3. There are a lot of characters that you see their development and growing in the anime and you don't even have a chance to play in PW4 because more than 2/3 of the anime are just cutscenes.
I won’t say anything about the online system, because I played the whole game solo. But you can read a few reviews saying that it is bugged and poorly implemented.
Bandai don't want you to struggle to get S ranks on all missions (as I said, it’s useless). They've made an easy and short game where you'll play only once the story mode, and if you want to have all the achievements, just play a few more missions of the Treasure Log. 
What about Free log? Pointless.
There isn’t any struggling point in PW4. Despite replaying a few missions, I completed the story mode in a few hours.

I've spent 130 hours on PW3 getting 100% of it. 
It took me just 29 hours on PW4, and I think I'll never touch it again.

I can't recommend a game that explores less than 1/3 of the anime.
It would be better if Whole Cake Island arc and Wano arc were launched for PW3 as a DLC.
They could have included ALL arcs on PW4. Too bad :(
It just seems like an unfinished game.

I rather wish I could recommend this game... I'm a long-time fan of the entire 'Warriors' style of games, and a somewhat-lapsed One Piece fan, so it's right up my alley. I played and enjoyed the first three games in the series, too. And... well, there's the rub. Frankly, to me, this sequel just doesn't feel like it's managing to justify its own existence.

Let me explain. Putting aside the first game - which was understandably quite experimental - the second title provided an engaging and original Warriors-style plot featuring all your favorite characters from One Piece. A perfect game for someone who just wants a fun and feisty hack-and-slash game featuring superpowered pirates instead of ancient Chinese heroes. The THIRD title provided a thorough exploration of the entire One Piece plot by way of hack-and-slash gameplay, clear from Luffy's first meeting with Zorro in East Blue and up to the confrontation with Doflamingo on Dressrosa, which was where the Anime was at the time. A perfect game for a One Piece fan who wants to play their way through somewhat exaggerated versions of all the major fights of the series.

This one, though... it's got a story mode, sure enough, following the plot of One Piece, but it's EXTREMELY abbreviated. ALL of East Blue is skipped along with the start of Grand Line, leaving you to start with the Alabasta Arc. Skypeia? Skipped. Thriller Bark? Skipped. Impel Down? Skipped. Fishman Island? Skipped. Punk Hazzard? Skipped. All the unique characters found in those places, who were playable in previous games? Gone. The interesting battlegrounds and armies found there? Gone. Dressrosa has been somewhat expanded, conversely, and Whole Cake Island has been added along with a game-original 'Wano Arc' tagged on at the end. So a lot less than what was dropped.

Enough new playable characters have been added to bring the total playable number up above what it was in the third game... though I'm honestly not sure HOW, since I keep noticing characters that are missing outright or have been demoted to non-playable. Also, some of the missing characters are being sold back to you as part of the extremely pricey Character Pass, which... just feels WRONG. I don't usually blame Bandai-Namco for their expensive DLC, since it's simply their way to deal with the rising price of AAA development, but selling you characters who were ALREADY PLAYABLE in the previous game just feels like cheating. And it still doesn't address the lack of variety in terms of battlefields...

Adding to my annoyance, there are a LOT of cutscenes. LONG cutscenes, cutscenes that try to bridge the huge gaps between chapters while still leaving out important details and defusing any emotional weight, cutscenes that appear in the middle of stages to interrupt the action, LOADS AND LOADS of very NICE cutscenes... but WHY?! There's an ANIME out there if you just want to WATCH One Piece. Why the heck didn't they spend all that time, money, effort and resources making more ACTUAL GAMEPLAY? More characters, more stages, more generic armies, maybe even more game-modes... I mean, yes, the story-mode obviously requires SOME cutscenes to be accessible, but you really don't need to be spoon-fed the ENTIRE plot when you can just GO WATCH THE ANIME if you want to.

So yeah. Why does this game need to exist? Between the second game, the third game, and the actual ANIME, everything it does has already been done better. The basic campaign is vastly inferior to the one from 3, the original Wano Arc is vastly inferior to the original plot from 2, and all it's really got going for it is a handful of new characters and transformations, and some halfway decent destructible environments. It doesn't even look noticeably better than the last two games. Just play them instead.

TL;DR: To quote one of my favorite reviewers, "I miss the days where sequels having MORE stuff was taken as read..."

A fantastic game! I recommend getting One Piece: Pirate Warriors 4!

This game is worth having as a One Piece fan and it`s a pretty decent musou game in general though it`s not without its flaws.

Pros

- Much better roster than Pirate Warriors 3, and the characters feel quite distinct. Additions like Kid, Hawkins, Reiju, and
  Carrot are lots of fun to play.

- Kaido's Dragon Form (and the Yonko in general) are insanely powerful and fun to play

- Better controller support than Pirate Warriors 3 but still requires some tweaking

- Pretty good quality cutscenes and animations

Cons

- Abridged story is hard to follow for beginners. Lots of important characters and side-plots are glossed over entirely. This 
  is definitely not how you want to get introduced to One Piece's story.

- The game content feels more sparse than Pirate Warriors 3. I should have 100% achievements and gotten S class finishes 
   on all missions (Story and Treasure Log) by about 35hrs in. Learning to use the entire roster will obviously add more time
   but I can't really see myself playing this for more than 70hrs in total if that.

- Camera is very slightly improved over Pirate Warriors but still pretty bad in general.

- The HUD gets cluttered very quickly and the minimap gets lit up like a Christmas tree which can make navigation a real 
   pain. 


Overall, I'd still recommend owning this game but don't buy it at full price. Wait for at least a 20-30% discount, and that's only if you're a One Piece fan. If you're new to the series or just like musou games, wait for something more steep like half off.

A wild departure from the PW series, and in many ways from the generic musou formula. One Piece: Pirate Warriors 4 combines an experimental intergration of aerial combos, fan service, and VASTLY improved online formats to deliver a refreshing entry. I really wanted to give this game a recommendation but with the reveal of the DLC characters my opinion was swayed negative. Don't get me wrong if you're a fan of One Piece and Warrior titles this game is fun. But they've done pretty much the same amount of negative changes as they did things right. The DLC characters however are the final nail for me because we already have 4 Germa 66 Characters and now we get another one. We already have a good amount of Charlotte Pirates but now get two more. Why aren't previously playable character no longer playable like : Caesar Clown, Perona, Gecko Moria, Magellan, Kuma, Enel and probably more. Why aren't characters like Mr 3/1 and many more avaible as Enemies but not playable? I really feel like they wasted some slots, especially 4 G66 characters, for Characters that deserved it more and also would've been more fun to play.

But let's get to the most annoying changes, because a Roster is always hard to select when you've got over 20 years to choose from.
Characters are now split into Power, Speed, Technik and Sky types.
This has turned some of my previous favorite characters into my least played characters. Because the new Full burst mode you can activate means you'll be hanging in the sky only using Aerial Combos and Attacks that all feel alot less powerful and effective than being on the ground.
To be fair however they've improved alot of the characters to be able to change somethings however, even though you only really feel this for Luffy and Sanjii. Luffy for example can activate gear 2/4/snakeman to change his moveset also changing his Type. I've always hated gear 4 and this makes gear 2 Luffy a viable option. However it feels like only a few characters received this overhaul. Chopper and Franky in my opinion really needed an Overhaul like that but didn't get it. Both of these Characters could've been great if you could just change their modes to get different skillsets...

The Special attack changes are mostly great.
You've now got 4 different special attacks you can choose from, however one of them should always be the Full burst mode whch is the new equivalent to Haki/Kizuna Rush from the old games. However as mentioned this turns Sky types into always flying characters that can't use ground moves. However choosing what ultimate attacks to use really allows some customization that feels great.

The new leveling system are essentially skilltrees which are a nice touch to level up characters the only thing I don't like is that it doesn't tell you where to find the coins you need to unlock special attacks. Which means you'll be scrolling through that mission list looking for things related to that character to find them.

Lastly are of course the actual roster and I've already mentioned that I'm missing some characters here. Logia users are no longer as much fun to play as they used to and I'm really missing Magellan here. It's a shame that Luffy, Sanjii and Zorro get 5-8 outfits while Nami only gets two playable outfits and Franky, Chopper, Brook and Robin all get no alternative outfits despite having alternative models in the game.
The game does have an great if not too large representation of the Big Mom storyline with atleast 10 and a few Worst Generation characters such as Kid, Bege, Hawkins making their debut, especially Kid play interesting while Bege is a summon type character that usually would be my favorite but this might be the worst version I've seen and I really liked this type in other Dynasty Warrior games. The Roster seems ok overall even though I'm really missing a few. Personally I would've cut atleast half of the new character to bring back Magellan, Enel, Perona and Kuma atleast if not a few never before playable characters from either CP9 or the Alabasta Saga. But that's just personal preference.

Anyway as I've said I'm really conflicted wether to give this a recommendation or not so it's a buy at discount  since it's good but it's not better than PW3

This is one of the best anime games I've played in a long while and I say props to both Bandai and Koei for not making this a cash grab.

First things first, the gameplay is superfluid. Everything flows nicely together, it's really a step-up from Pirate Warriors 3.
Also, the game is not locked to 30 FPS. One more reason why it feels super smooth. It's absolutely amazing playing the game at a nice 60 FPS. 

The visuals are also really good. Very good, no more PS Vita and switch port for us PC folks. 

Another plus is that controllers work fine, all with button prompts. For those who played Pirate Warriors 3 you know how much this was a problem then. 

I'm yet to try the online, but with the experience I'm getting now I doubt that will be a problem. 

All in all, I just hope Bandai continues with this trend because all I can say is if some anime games were like this (cough cough Jump force and One punch man), we anime fans would have been very happy.

(TL;DR) If you liked Pirate Warriors 3, you'll love this.

Where PW3's story log covered the majority of One Piece from the start to the Dressrosa Arc, this installment gives a brief overview of early events with the earliest level taking place at the end of the Alabasta Arc. After getting caught up to where the previous game left off and properly finishing Dressrosa, the story goes through Whole Cake Island, skipping Zou for the most part, and finally (to a certain point) the Wano Arc. It should be mentioned that at this point the game continues with its own original story, as the Wano Arc is still in progress at the time of this game's release.

Gameplay-wise it's more of the same from PW3 but with more polish and a different roster of characters. Also the absurd grinding needed to get certain coins has been done away with and made MUCH more streamline while also making leveling individual characters less of chore.

Massive downgrade compared to PW3.

Cons:
1. 2/3-3/4 of the entire One Piece story is missing.
2. Less maps, at only 16.
3. Too many WCI characters who shouldn't even be in at all. All of Sanji's brothers did not need to be playable over the likes of Garp or Perona.
4. The Character Pass DLC looks like it has even more pointless characters from the most overutilized arc: WCI.
5. No level up system, instead you have to spend millions of Beli on character upgrades.
6. No reason to play each level more than once for story mode, because you don't unlock anything for unlocking hidden events or getting all S ranks.
7. Free Log is pointless.
8. East Blue is mentioned in Treasure Log, but none of the bad guy characters or maps from the arcs are in.
9. Too many cutscenes to explain what we just missed.
10. Long loading times.
11. No explanation as to why certain arcs are skipped.

Pros:
1. Better graphics.
2. Giant characters are proper sized.
Addictive.  Obviously mainly for fans of the show, but if you keep up with One Piece, don't miss this one.

One Piece: Pirate Warriors 4 takes the series to new heights with revamped combat and progression mechanics. In addition to these new mechanics comes new story missions including a canon ending to the Dressrosa, Whole Cake Island, and Wano Country. On top of all this, stunning new soundtracks, visuals, and playable characters help make this game feel like a worthy purchase. My only gripes with the game are how much of the story is glossed-over, with only a handful of crucial arcs left in a playable state. This is especially a bummer considering how much of the story was covered in the previous games. Still, this game set out what it wanted to do, which is deliver us new content from previously untouched arcs in the manga and anime. It is an addicting game and one that I can see myself playing for months on end. If you're a fan of either One Piece or other Musou (Warrior) games, this one is a must-play!

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
One Piece Pirate Worries 4 is based on the hit anime [b]One Piece[/b] and is the predecessors of the three other games in the series. Combat is played the same, however, it is tweaked and is more smooth and air combat is much better as well. The game is sure to keep fans of [b]One Piece[/b], both casual and hardcore invested with its wonderful gameplay and retelling of the story.  

[h1]Pros and Cons[/h1]
[h3]Pros[/h3]
+ A great retelling of the [b]One Piece[/b] story.
+ Fun gameplay that can sometimes even be addictive
+ Both casual and hardcore [b]One Piece[/b] fans can find enjoyment in this game
+ Over 43 different characters to play as, plus a season pass with some more.
+ Four different subtypes to play as.

[h3]Cons[/h3]
- Gameplay may get stale for some people. 
- Some fan-favorite arks did not make it into the game.
- Some of the characters that were playable in OPW3 are not playable in this game. 

[h1]Story[/h1]
The game’s story follows the anime’s story and plays it through arks with a few levels in each and every word. The story of One Piece is great and the game tells it very well with the arks that we have been giving, the story has the One Piece charm and that is something that all fans can enjoy. 

However, not all arks made it into the game and fan favorites were removed as well. The entire [b]East Blue Saga[/b] was cut, the game starts at [b]Alabasta[/b], so no [b]Drum Island ark[/b], [b]Skypiea[/b] was removed, [b]Thriller Bark[/b], [b]Impel Down[/b], [b]Fish-Man Island[/b], and [b]Punk Hazard[/b] were also removed. This is disappointing, mainly because a lot of [b]One Piece[/b] fans loved some of these arks. [b]Enel[/b] and [b]Magellan[/b] were not even shown in the story or mentioned, however, [b]Gecko Moria[/b] was shown once in the story when the game was talking about [b]Thriller Bark[/b]. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Gameplay in the game is very fun and can be addictive at times as well, there are many characters for you to select sometimes depending on the mission you are giving. Each character has its own moves and has one of the four subtypes, Power, Speed, Technique, and Sky. Some characters can be a certain subtype in the Pre-time skip but have different moves in the Post-time Skip due to certain transformations, for example, Sanji is a speed type in the Pre-time skip but at the Post-time skip, he will be a Sky type due to some of his moves been modified.  

Every character has three special moves and a mode where they can be powered up and do extra damage. Most of these special moves will take out most enemies and will do a large chunk of damage to bosses. At some point, characters will enter a [b]Full-Force Burst[/b] mode, when this mode is activated they will get a special benefit depending on their subtype. 

[h3]Power Types[/h3]
Power Types are centered around the fact that they can deal large amounts of damage and take out enemies very quickly. When a power type character is hit by an enemy, a wall, or the floor, a shock wave is sent out and will damage any enemies that are near it. When power types are in [b]Full-Force Burst[/b], they will get more attack damage and their smash attacks are more powerful.  

[h3]Speed Types[/h3]
Speed types are more focused on combat as they have combo potential, and they can move around very fast, their stamina usage is also reduced in a power dash. When Speed types are in [b]Full-Force Burst[/b], their stamina usage is greatly reduced in a power dash. 

[h3]Technique Types[/h3]
Technique types are the most interesting as they have special moves that affect gameplay, like putting enemies to sleep, using oil, and lighting it up to make fire, and there is so much more. Technique types can also perform an attack while charging that will push enemies towards them. When a Technique type enters [b]Full-Force Burst[/b] their special traits of that character are powered up.  

[h3]Sky Types[/h3]
Sky types are a bit weird at first but they focus on air combat and have the most characteristics out of all the types. They are immune to all damage during a power dash, their power dash counties until all the stamina is used up, enemies that are not on the ground can get caught up in their power dash, and they can use stamina to start an attack when falling from an aerial attack. When a Sky type goes [b]Full-Force Burst[/b], they will have the ability to float constantly and their stamina usage is decreased during a power dash.  

[h1]Combat[/h1]
Combat is like other [b]Dynasty Worries[/b] games and the main objective for every single mission is to beat up a bunch of enemies, beat up leaders to take over territories to get more minions to help you fight. At some point, you will fight a mini-boss or a boss, when bosses come out they will have an [b]Armor Gauge[/b] if you remove all of the [b]Armor Gauge[/b] they will be stunned and put into a state called [b]Armor Break State[/b], in which they will take more damage.
Depending on who you fight, that characters [b]Devil Fruit[/b] may come into play as well if the character has one of course. [b]Peramecia[/b] and [b]Zeons[/b] don’t really have any gimmicks when it comes to attacking them other than the fact that their devil fruit is their move set mostly. However, if a Logia activates their ability, their appearance can change and normal attacks will not harm them. To harm someone with a Logia they will need to be put in their armor break state and all attacks will harm them when they are in this state.

[h3]Sub-Missions[/h3]
Sometimes a [b]Sub-Mission[/b] may take place during the level at a certain location or if you do certain requirements, these [b]Sub-Missions[/b] can be things like normal missions as well when the time comes for them. If you are able to complete these missions, then you will get rewarded barries which is the currency for the game.  

[h1]Dreamlog[/h1]
[b]Dreamlog[/b] is a mode that lets you play a bunch of missions, in this mode, you can get barries that help you level up your characters. [b]Dream log[/b] has you do the same missions as what the story mode provides but it’s mostly just you fighting a bunch of enemies, you will have different characters that will team up with you. You can play as any character in this mode if you have them unlocked, some character can only be unlocked in [b]Dreamlog[/b] after completing certain missions. 

[h1]What Holds The Game Back[/h1]
The gameplay is fun but it can get stale sometimes, especially after you are done completing the story. [b]Dream Log[/b] is a nice feature but you are doing the same thing over and over again and there is really no motive to continue playing. 

[h1]Preformance[/h1]
I was able to play the game in high settings, I used a NIVIDA GeForce GTX 1060 3GB, 16 GB of RAM storage on a 2560:1440 [16:9] monitor. The game runs really smooth and I had no issues what so ever while playing, the game may look like you need a good computer, but if you have a decent computer, you should be able to run the game in low settings.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
One Piece Pirate Worries 4 is a great addition to the series and is a wonderfully made game, I have been an avid player of the previous game and this one proves once again why this series is great. Fans of the series can look forward to more of what they’ve come to love and expect.

One Piece Pirate Warriors 4 is by far the best anime adapted game I've ever played, and my favorite Musou title of all time.
There's so much things this game did right, and so much was improved from the previous installment.

Let's start with the roster. You get to play as your favorite characters from One Piece. From the basic Straw Hat Crew to Katakuri to Law, all favourites were included in the game. I always dream of letting me experience as the characters in One Piece, using different techniques to defeat enemies. Now you can, using different combos to defeat hordes of minions. It's so satisfying to launch a Red Hawk and wipe out over 50 enemies in an instant, or create a ROOM and see all minions turn into bombs, or use Gear 4th Bounce Man to just jump around.

Speaking of techniques, the combat is so good. The last installment isn't bad, using a combination of Triangles and Squares (or X and Y Buttons) to launch different combos, and usually 2 specials  and 1 awakening for each character. This time it's just a straight improvement from the last one. More combos and specials included, and 4 specials/awakenings can be used at once. Now you can be awakened, Bounce Man and Snake Man at the same time. Or use all Zoro's New World Techniques at the same time. Now that's dope.

The introduction of animation cancel is also really fun and makes the game more fast paced, comfortable and make the skill ceiling higher. You feel so much more powerful using different cancels, usually attack-dash combos, and it feels so much less clunky compared to OPPW3.

Air Combos are fun as hell. Using Sky characters to use air combos continuously is hella fun. Sanji with Sky Walk awakening and keep jingling Katakuri non-stop is both hilarious and insanely fun. 

And most importantly, all characters feel fun and unique to play. OPPW3 is fun, but once you realised the strongest characters and start spamming them with their broken moves like Fujitora throughout the Treasure Log, the game just gets stale real quick. Now it feels like every character has their own niche to try out and have fun with. Usopp's explosive combos are fun as hell, so is Hancock's immobilizing moves and Law's Room moves.

There's so much good things about the combat and characters, I haven't even touch on the story mode. Unlike the previous title where it goes through all islands from Shells Town to Dressrosa, this time they include the most memorable moments only, so starting from the Alabasta, Water 7/Enies Lobby, Sabaody/Marineford, Dressrosa, Whole Cake Island and Finally Wano. And most importantly, the Game Original story of Wano is so good. Compared to OPPW3, where the Dressrosa original story is an absolute mess, OPPW4's Wano original story is actually interesting and fun to watch. Seeing how Katakuri, Kid and Luffy work together is incredible, or having Bartolomeo & Cavendish come to Wano after listening to Luffy's news is really heartwarming. The final clash is real cool and intense, and the animation against Kaido is well done. It's a really unforgettable experience.

Overall a very solid beat'em up game. This review is finished by the time I've finished the main story missions, and I can't wait to jump into Treasure mode and experience more new characters.

So far I like the game a lot, this is the second time I have purchased the game, the first being on the switch. After I realized that the game had severely cut back graphic features like no grass, I needed to get it on PC. I also miss having more of an option to choose which character you play as during the story, because I don’t ever want to play as usopp. I don’t think anyone wants to play as usopp. I am enjoying the game but so far the combos for pre time skip zoro and Sanji feel kind of stiff. Then again I have not mastered that games new fighting mechanic nor have I gotten all the skills the game for them. I have high hopes for the game and if you are a fan of pirates, one piece, anime, or dynasty warrior games I recommend this game.

EDIT: After having plenty of time with the game, and having gotten 100% of the achievements with it I can say that I fully recommend this game. One of my previous grips with the game was that the combat was kinda clunky, but after learning how to play with the new mechanics I find it even better than in PW3. Some characters are clearly better than others, like kaido, big mom, and whitebeard completely destroy everything in this game, all of them have 4 equivalent of kizuna rushes (except kaido, but his xxyyy combo is insane). I wish the move sets were just better, Aokiji hits like a wet noodle, and his powerful specials don't do enough damage, or just plain miss the enemies. As a One Piece fan, who really enjoyed OPPW3, this game was really enjoyable.

+ Very different Characters. If you get bored by one, you can always play with another - the feeling is guaranteed to be different.
+ Even the characters, who are of the same type (Power, Sky, Technique and Speed) are very different from each other. Yes, they have similar traits, but you always know that you are playing Luffy and not just a Power Type Character, for example.
+ Maps are gorgeous, even though they are pretty similar to each other (which can be Considered a -). The destructible terrain makes it more realistic and makes you feel even more powerful.
+ Music is awesome. I personally like the OPPW3 tunes more, but these are not bad as well and the fact you can choose your favorites whenever you want is cool.
+ Cinematics are very well made - they make the stories much more enjoyable (at least during the first play through :D)

- The Story is most likely not gonna be able to grab the casual player, if they are not a One Piece fan and haven't watched the anime or read the manga. A lot of arcs were skipped, which they tried to fill with cutscenes between the in-game arcs, but I, personally, think it's pretty difficult to follow the story still.
- The game is pretty repetitive after you complete the Story and might get boring for some. DLC's are coming, which will likely fix that, but if you're not a fan of repetitive gameplay, you'll likely quit the game very fast.

Overall, I think the game does what it aims to do - provide a fun experience for the One Piece and Musou fans with a lot of the most-loved and popular Characters from the anime. If you're a One Piece fan, I definitely recommend it, you're gonna have a blast. I know I did.

One Piece Pirate Warriors 4 so far has been an amazing sequel in the series with very minimal flaws.  To start off as with the track record of previous PW games, the roster got beefed up, and while there were a few characters from PW3 who were cut, the games base roster is bigger than any previous installments and has a character pass which will be adding 9 more characters total to the roster.  As far as character variety goes, this game has it.

Campaign Review:  The main campaign of the game is one of the things I see that is most upsetting to people, and understandably so.  In PW4, a few arcs have been cut, which means you aren't getting the entire experience of One Piece, however the fact that each arc has a few missions instead of each arc BEING a mission or 2, makes them more worthwhile to take home.  As far as length of the campaign, it still is something to sink time in to and feels very rewarding.

Treasure Log:  The Treasure Log is PW4's post game option which consists of multiple, non canon scenarios that add interesting team ups and rivalries.  Treasure Log is where you will be spending most of the time in the game for it's load of missions as well as character grinding purposes, missions also get progressively harder as you go through the three tiers (East Blue, Grand Line and New World).  It is a very fulfilling and good time killing post game to sink into .

Overall:  An absolutely BEAUTIFUL game, with amazing graphics, fluent combo structures with the addition of air combat and being able to replace skills and form changes, I feel Pirate Warriors 4 takes the cake on being the best game in the series.  Absolutely would recommend, Pirate Warriors 4 is worth it!

Personally I like the game quite alot, though it has some flaws. The combat system is quite fluid, while it limits you to a ground and a air combat chain, it allows you to extend combos with the dash and change into the air combat chain whenever you want with a launch attack. Also the characters play quite different and usually have access to their iconic moves. Sadly some characters from the previous game arent in this anymore (especially as playable characters) like Kuma or Hannyabal. And here we come to a quite troublesome choice in terms of the games desing: The Story Missions. While the story arc usually get a good batch of missions to represent them, all with a certain ammount of maps of various sizes (usually cut into pieces for missions rarely left in One Piece ;) ) the game focuses in contrast to PW3 only on a hand full of arcs jumping from one to another (Arcs that actually made it in the game: Alabasta, Water 7/ Enis Lobby, Sabody Archipelago (befor time skip), Marine Fort, Sabody Archipelago (post time skip), Dressarosa, Whole Cake Island Arc and the Wano Arc (with a custom end like they did in PW 3 with Dressarosa). Also having alot of non playable characters in there that only function as enemies (usually most of the underlings in dressarosa and Wano, also drake) while some didnt make it in the game at all (just saying Biscuit isnt a thing in this game.). The lack of different scenes kinda hurts the treasure log due to it playing on allways the same maps, which are usually quite well desinged and big but at some point it kinda hurts the game. A good point are the transformations that actually change the gameplay of the character a bit though only a vew characters have access to it (sadly Chopper and Franky dont belong to those chosen vew). So I can only hope that they ll add missing arcs as dlc, though as far as I know Bandai Namco most of the stuff will be costumes...

Pro:
[list]
    [*]Online Co-Op
    [*]Transformations
    [*]Giant Sized Characters
    [*]Better and longer Combos

    [*]4 Skills can be equipped at once => More Diversity in Co-Op. Everyone plays differently
[/list]

Con:
[list]
    [*]Some Cutscenes where taken from Pirate Warriors 3 (PS3 Era) and you can see the improvement of the Cutscenes with the newer Arcs
    [*]Only 8 Arcs of the whole One Piece Story. They removed the Arcs like the Baratie Arc, Arlong Park Arc, Loguetown, Skypiea, Thriller Bark, Impel Down, Fish-Man Island, Punk Hazard (All of them were playable in Pirate Warriors 3).
    [*]Removed Non-playable Enemy Characters you fought in the previous Games like Captain Morgan, Hody Jones, Alvida and more
[/list]

I think my favorite thing about PW4 is that it doesn't eliminate PW3 and make it a dead game in your library. Now of course this will vary from person to person and what they enjoy about these games as a whole, but personally I love to see what different aspects and systems a musou focuses on and how they're implemented.

PW4 is different enough from PW3 that it felt like a fresh experience, even when the story was retreading old waters. Personally I was a fan of the focus on later stages of the story, as these games tend to draw in a particular crowd that probably doesn't need to fight Don Kreig for the 20th year in a row.

The Gameplay is a whole different beast from PW3. The trait button for characters is gone, those moves instead being placed into their kit in a more streamlined fashion. There's a high emphasis on expanding aerial combat, most likely due to the existence of giant type enemies and bosses. This doesn't detract from the flow of combat however, and the high speed of the Pirate Warriors games is still there, if a bit gimped by a stamina meter stopping you from dash cancelling 100 times in a row.

Overall, its a great experience. The optional grind is still there as always, though lacking a bit in character as optional missions become a list rather than islands you explore between. Hopefully updates to the game will bring with them more character and life, but even as it is now the game rests on equal footing with its predecessor.

Very fun and entertaining game. Played a lot of musou game over multiple consoles, this one easily on top 3.

Below are the pros and cons for this game, in comparison with previous game, Pirate Warriors 3.

Pros:
- Better graphics.
- Better gameplay.
- More playable characters. Previous game has 37, this one 43 + 9 from DLC.
- Characters are more diversed, gameplay wise. The addition of "character type", "character size", and "airborne attack" really change the feels and perspective of a musou game.
- Each maps are more unique. No more "square area" scattered all over the map.
- Customizable list of special moves.

Cons:
- The game includes new arc and expands arc from previous title, but they also remove some arcs, like Skypiea and Thriller Bark.
- Seven of playable characters were cut (Enel, Moria, Perona, Kuma, Garp, Caesar, and Magellan). They haven't however reveal the 9 characters for DLC. So, some of them might return as additional paid content.
- Pre-Time Skip of Nami, Chopper, Brook, Robin, and Franky also not playable. But this one is not that big of a deal since the post-TS version of characters that have playable pre-TS easily overshadow their pre-TS version.
- No more Dream Log. While I don't like Dream Log from previous game, they can do something to improve the mode instead of replacing it with a new mode that's basically just a long list of missions.

Overall, I'll give this game 8.5/10.

If you like hack and slash games plus love One Piece, this is a must!

This is my first Pirate Warriors game. At first I was worried that it was not deep enough or would become repetitive, and even though it is a little repetitive, the smooth fighting mechanics, RPG elements and reliving the Once Piece story has kept me hooked. Totally Worth it. 

P.S In doubt, just wait for it to go on sale. It will give it time to clean up the bugs some people are having, even though I have not experienced any myself.

As a fan of one piece, this game is really fun! Really lets you live the power fantasy of literally breaking the air with Whitebeard or turning everyones heads into bombs with Law. Also lots of progression, easy to play for hours on end trying to level up every character!

This is a must have for everyone who ever enjoyed One Piece in their lives, possibly even to people who had no prior experience with the series. It's better than Pirate Warriors 3, which was already incredible, in basically every aspect, Smoother gameplay, better graphics, more interesting character progression, destructible terrain...all that good stuff. All the canonical techniques from One Piece are here, characters, locations, which also includes all the newer stuff like Big Mom, Kaido, etc.

The only possible downside I can find is the story. It seems they wanted to fit the whole of One Piece in this game for some reason, which results in like 75% of it being cut out, or told to us by narrator through cutscenes. If you know the story from the manga or the anime this won't be an issue, but people who hope to follow the plot through the game will probably not be able to do that here. I wish they'd just started from a later part of the story and followed it more closely instead.

Recommend this game if you're a one piece fan. 
Otherwise.... no.

One of the newest in the series and many gameplay improvements compared to the last game. Having been following the series from the first game I gotta say this edition has the most 'immerson' in terms of story battles, in that there are multiple maps (typically 5~7) per arc. Progressing through the Onepiece storyline is more akin to the manga/anime experience and in-depth with the major highlights of each arc. 

Combat is slightly different with 4 assigned skills with the shift key and combos that are either longer and activated mid-air for some aerial characters. I do have to make the point that quite a few character has lost a bit of mobility compared to OPPW3, so AOE and large swiping attacks are less prevalent in this game. Also, characters with special forms like luffy will have a complete different set of skills and combo when activated. 

Gameplay for the campaign is roughly 15 hours as many said, and the 'dream log' end game content in this game is a similarly progressive form of individual levels, with increasing character stat requirements. This, I comment, feels less diverse and exploratory than OPPW3, the missions are more or less random and some players may lose interest.

Having said all that I still believe it is worthwhile to invest IF you are a hardcore One Piece fan and is willing to support the developer's OP related franchise. However, if you are new to the anime/manga or this type of BN musou game in general I'd recommend the wait for a sale. This game does contain major spoilers and a custom Wano arc ending.

Melhor edição até agora da franquia Pirate Warriors. A nova engine é fantástica, as lutas tem agora o tom do anime com a nova funcionalidade de destruição de cenário, sem falar em poder jogar (ou batalhar contra) com personagens gigantes que é alucinante. O sistema de batalhas aéreas também ficou muito bom e permite combos jamais possíveis antes em PW. Cada personagem conta com muito golpes selecionáveis na tela de preparação e só vai aumentando de acordo com o nível de evolução de cada um. Os cenários evoluíram muito também, visto que agora contam com topologia/relevo super variada e de acordo realmente com cada local do mundo de One Piece. Essa ambientação deixa cada mapa completamente diferente um do outro e não mais "cidades" feitas de quadrados no mapa.

Não importa se você já jogou os PW anteriores ou não; se gosta de One Piece e curte games estilo musou, Pirate Warrios 4 é o melhor que você pode ter!

Alright, wanted to wait for platinum, but that's gonna take some grinding, so here's a quick review.

It's pretty much the same old formula and it works here, too. There are quite a few changes to the core gameplay, but they all pretty much work together well and soon you'll be jumping, transforming and dabbling with different supers all over the place.

Supers are so much better in this one, since you just go from 1 to 4 supers, that you can also swap around, if you like a different kind of super more.

The roster is big, quickly unlocked and has lotsa different characters, that all play at least somewhat differently. Seeing the super clear the screen or wipe like 3 commanders is still immensely satisfying.

The "leveling" system is weird at first and pretty intuitive after looking at it a bit. You get one general "tree" for passive skills, that affects all characters. Then you get 2 separate trees for each character, the second one being unlocked after working with that char for a bit, either by having them exist in quests or just by playing them. Just make sure you actually switch over to the character sheet in the first few hours, because that's where you unlock actual combos and supers, which makes fights a lot easier (and more fun).

One negative regarding the leveling is that it's not quite transparent and needlessly complicated menuing. First off, it seems to be built around slow progression. There's no way to dump your resources and just buy all the upgrades in one node. You have to go to the node, click upgrade, navigate to "yes" in the pop-up, confirm and then you need to do the same thing again for all skill points.

And the later you get in the game, the more frustrating this gets, with you suddenly having WAY more resources and maybe wanting to switch to a different character, but then spending 5 minutes in the menu constantly pressing the same buttons.

You also can't easily check which quests you get coins from (that are shown in your tree). There's no "complete xyz to unlock" or anything. And then you also get the hidden nodes, that literally force you to guess what the ability is and how to unlock it. The "coin unlock guide" doesn't give you much relevant info. It's also really badly placed, because you'd basically need to write down the coin you wanna check, then completely go out of the character select, exit mission select, go to the main menu, select gallery, select the coin guide, flick through every coin and compare to the coin you wrote down.

Sounds long and complicated? Yeah, try doing that like 10 times for different skills and you quickly kinda stop caring. I'm currently looking for a coin that unlocks, what I presume to be a super for Whitebeard and it's just "oh is it this quest? No? Cool, time to waste another 5 minutes".

It's forced stretching of gameplay and it's too obvious and annoying to be interesting. You wanna do the treasure log with your favorite character and all their cool stuff? Ok, screw you, try guessing which of the hardest quests will get you that move you maybe want and grind for it.

And that brings us to difficulty. I played on normal, but there's a hard option right from the start and an "ultra hard" option that unlocks after the story. I found the difficulty to be quite ok. It's surprisingly much harder than the previous OP musou, but that doesn't mean it's difficult per se. It's just a little bit tougher than "mash buttons = win". You'll actually need to dodge some of the stronger attacks later on and be on top of your leveling. S rank can be a bit tough to achieve on your first run through the log, considering some of the objectives have you guess what's the fastest way to complete. It's often the time that was the issue for me; kills are usually easier to get, but vary wildly from 1k to 2.5k or more.

What can also kill your S ranks, are the weirdly useless sub-missions. Do not go for any submissions. All you get for completing them is a tiny bit of money at the end and very rarely a small bonus to aid you on the battlefield (like preventing reinforcements). Sub-missions will usually get you around 1/10th of the berry prize at the end, while attaining S rank will literally get you double the reward money.

And as ok as the difficulty is, the "new world" logs are gonna pretty much kill you, even if your character is maxed, in around 5-6 hits, depending on the enemy. You also get swarmed with tons of named characters that can all interrupt you, meaning you sometimes can't even get away, especially if you locked on and are now flying in a circle on accident. Buuut, if you now equip a self-buff and the "heal while self-buffed" skill, you suddenly have no issue with dying anymore, because the heal is so substantial.

Last point, if you like that stuff: Trophies
They are some of the easiest trophies to get in any game I've ever played. You will get more than half just from playing story stuff, more than 3/4 if you go for a bit of grinding and I'm 2 away from full trophies; literally just need to amass money now.

That's in part due to the fact that there are no trophies for different difficulty levels. There's no trophy for completely s-ranking the story (which I stupidly didn't look up) and also no trophy for completely s-ranking the treasure log or maxing out all characters, maxing out the trees of one character, even.

Tl;dr: It's an improvement of OPW3, controller issues seem mostly resolved (although my game switches my keyboard input to a different layout every time) and it's still the good old "get big numbers; do the cool move" gameplay that you play dynasty warrior games for.

If you like this kinda gameplay and OP, this is a pretty neat game to pick up. If not, the gameplay's gonna feel a little shallow and you'll wonder who different characters are and why they're capable of weird stuff.

If you liked the past titles for the fun move sets and total battlefield chaos, you'll find lots of fun here.

The game is based on the one-piece series and its main arcs. Even if you haven't seen the series, you will learn from the characters the characters' personality. You will learn to love the characters and the game and want to keep playing. And for those who have seen the series, the game will be no less good.

Having played this game A LOT, I can say it's great. I'll run it down more detailed, but tldr: controller support is there (just needs to be enabled in properties>and controller settings), and I play on an XOne mini and it functions perfectly, the game looks good, the combo system is fun and there's a lot to sink time into. 
Now let's get more into it. 

The story: the story covers from [spoiler] Alabasta [/spoiler] to [spoiler] Wano [/spoiler] ,although it's apart from the very beginning a game original. It does briefly cover them but gameplay-wise skips over [spoiler] Thriller Bark [/spoiler] , [spoiler] Impel Down [/spoiler] , [spoiler] Fishman Island [/spoiler] , [spoiler] Punk Hazard [/spoiler] and [spoiler] Zou [/spoiler] . Playing coop (Ill cover it too) we finished the story in 20 hours. The maps are also really well done to represent the actual layout used in the anime/manga this time around.

The gameplay: classic musou style combat, aerial combos add more depth from previous titles. Musou/special attacks are a grid now, where you "build a loadout" of 4 different ones, ranging from traditional cutscene-y musous to transformations to heals/buffs to basic empowered versions of special attacks. Overall, very fun combat.

Other notable stuff: Coop works well and you can experience all story/treasure log maps in 2p coop, as well as a few dozen treasure log maps that can be played with up to 4 players (empty slots are filled with AI). The progression has been made interesting and instead of just levelling up you use coins and berries to progress the abilities of your characters.

Negatives: In coop the timing for invites is awkward, and sometimes I'd end up with a random player joining me before my friend could join. Also there are multiple major characters missing that were included in previous games, and while there are 9 upcoming dlc chars, missing chars they already had movesets for is kinda sad.

Overall, the game is really good and I can easily recommend it to any warriors/one piece fan

100% it in 2 days. This is the best pirate warriors to date. 

===================================================================
The Good Stuff:

+++ The Y / Triangle string has been removed and has been replaced with each character's unique action. It has the best move-set for all characters due to the new Jump action, harder characters like Marco plays better in this than in Pirate Warriors 3. Extremely powerful characters like Kizaru from Pirate Warriors 3 is completely balanced in this, that being said, he is still incredibly op.

++ There is a new stamina system where you cannot spam attacks using dash and constantly stun-lock your enemy anymore. Some SKY characters like Kizaru have the ability to dash across the map, flying over buildings and enemy while using up his stamina.

+ There is destructible environment in this game. This greatly help the game to look like One Piece when every fight has a building destroyed.

+ It is also easier to 100% this game since the crew level system is greatly improved. It takes a few battles to level them up to MAX which is so much better as you need the coins from them to upgrade your characters and unlock new moves. In Pirate Warriors 3, you had to really grind the crew level system to get certain skills or a better version of an already unlocked skills. 

===================================================================
The Not So Good Stuff:

-- However there is a lack of content? Some characters from Pirate Warriors 2/3 are not here, costumes and outfits from previous are also not included. Smaller arcs like Romance Dawn and Arlong Park are completely omitted.

- Bosses like Drake are incredibly frustrating to fight when using taller characters like Katakuri, basically Drake's hitbox causes you to go up in the air when you are attacking him which switches your X / Square attacks to be Air attacks.

===================================================================

Overall 10/10, Charlotte Katakuri is way too over-powered like Hello? If there is any missions I could not get rank S in. I just swap to Katakuri.

A much improved upon sequel to the PW saga, new moves and playable characters, whole new typings and great aerial mode. The improved graphics are great and the new maps are amazing too. 

I feel the only two downsides are that there have been a lot of arcs skipped in the story mode, think of Thriller Bark (Brook comes just out of nowhere and Gecko Moria isn't even in the game anymore), Drum (no Wapol, Chopper joining has a little monologue cutscene and that's it), Skypea (RIP Enel), Impel Down (Magellan), and even post timeskip the entire Fishmen Island and Punk Hazard arcs are skipped, Zou in its entirety is skipped aswell.

Also like mentioned above alot of previous (playable) characters have been removed which is a great shame.

But honestly other than that the game is amazing, the combat is even more fun than before, there is actual online play now, there is alot to grind which is a great timesink if you are a big completionist, and every character feels fun to play.

8/10 - Not a perfect One Piece tribute, but Musou games have never been better. Full review below.

= Intro =

Love 'Musou' games, love One Piece. Recently started playing Berserk again, really looked forward to this after the letdown of DOOM: Eternal.

= Gameplay = 

It's a Musou. You play an absurdly powerful hero and beat up literally thousands of enemies with a variety of splashy attacks and combos, while conquering territory to spawn thousands of your own troops.

PW3 was a lot of fun, but felt floaty, repetitive and bland at times. Fortunately PW4 fixes a whole lot of that - combat is meatier, the new specials system is a fantastic improvement, boss fights are now fully realized and have some interesting mechanics (although Pica in particular reveals one of the game's biggest remaining flaws) and you even have a rudimentary skill tree - although not quite as good as Berserk's loot/crafting system. 

Story mode is solid, with a few caveats - and the Treasure Log (similar to the Dream/Nightmare log of the previous game) is a huge improvement, with some genuinely creative and fun mission goals.

Characters are well designed and varied, with each one having a unique mechanic or two. 

Honestly, gameplay wise there isn't much to complain about here. As a Musou, this feels like the genre is heading towards some point where it's going to explode into the mainstream.

Everything feels like an upgrade - maps are bigger, enemies are more plentiful, tons of little refinements and improvements all over the place. As a game, it's really good.

That said, there are some issues. I don't like having to play through the story to unlock the majority of characters - in the previous game you could earn them gradually through the Log mode. 

I don't like how much content the game skips over (more below) and the difficulty settings feel out of whack. Hard is great - if you don't mind a bit of grinding and a *huge* difficulty spike midway through, Normal is 'my first Musou game' and Easy is 'my drunk cat's first Musou game'. 

= Graphics & Audio =

While it's not going to knock your socks off, it's a much prettier game (and a great PC port) - with stuff like tesselation adding a lot of visual oomph. The game does look slightly washed out, but pumping up the vibrancy with something like Reshade works well.

However, the camera - a common problem in Musous is really bad here. The inclusion of gigantic enemies makes it worse, when the camera zooms out and starts clipping into the boss, the scenery etc. It's been a problem for a while in the genre, and the general excellence of the game makes it more obvious over time.

Music is solid, but I turned it off after a while. 

= Style =

This is where PW4 comes a bit short. As a game, on it's own merits, it's great. As a One Piece tribute, it's...complicated. Rather than focusing on the *entire* story of OP, PW4 instead cuts things down and focuses more on depth within each arc. However, this feels a little odd sometimes - so many really great bits of the story are cut here. No Skypeia, no Thriller Bark, no Impel Down, no Zou, no Fishman Island. And yes, this means that most of the characters from these arcs are cut too - no Enel, Moria, Magellan etc.

The real shame though is that the later arcs that PW3 didn't get to also feel a bit thin. Whole Cake island is done decently, but Dressrosa is ridiculously cut down - the only Doflamingo Family characters are Diamante and Pica (neither are playable). No Trebol, no Baby 5, no Gladius and you never get to play Greenbit, the underground docks etc. Meh.

If they wanted to cut redundant content and focus on newer stuff, why not cut Alabasta and give us a more fully realized version of Dressrosa?

Beyond this, there are a few fully realized characters in the game that are not playable - evidently being kept back for DLC. I despise DLC in a AAA priced game like this.

= Value =

There is a *lot* of game here. 36 main story missions (although it's more like 30, as quite a few of these are just boss fights. Beyond this, you've got the excellent new Treasure Log to play, online features etc. Definitely good value even at a AAA price - although, again, I dislike how much was cut and the evident DLC shenanigans going on here.

I do wish skill trees were a bit more fleshed out, but with a cast of 40+ characters, that may be a bit ambitious.

= Overall =

+ The best Musou game to date.
+ Insanely fun.
+ Plenty of content.
+ Lots of improvements and added features.

Been a One Piece fan for years now, I love the story, the characters, the humor, everything. As a long time fan this game has been just one MASSIVE disappointment. The "Dramatic Log" being the main story, skipped over a disgusting amount of the source material. After glossing over all of the East Blue Saga (the beginning adventures of One Piece, where much of the world and it's rules are explained) you abruptly start halfway through the Alabasta Arc. This game is very obviously targeting long time fans, they expect you to know 90% of this stuff going in, but they continue on at a break-neck pace to the point where the game condenses whole chunks of story into miniature cut scenes. Typically, though momentarily, touching upon the more memorable scenes from the source material. Honestly the last Pirate Warriors game did a much better job going through the story.

Aside from the bungling of a main story, there's the "Treasure Log" game mode, specifically there to run you through hypothetical battles and situations in order to give character specific coins that'll allow you to get specific upgrades to certain characters. 

Honestly the game play isn't half bad, (aside from the occasional frame drop) it runs great, looks pretty good too and I'd say it's exactly what you expect from a "Dynasty Warriors" type game, just a cathartic action game, smashing through hoards of enemies and using coins and berries to level up the various characters to make it easier to smash through hoards of enemies. If that's your jam, more power to you, it's a pretty decent game if that's all you care about. Me personally being a long time fan, I'll still play it but I am thoroughly upset at how the story was portrayed. I was hoping to get my friends into One Piece through this game and unfortunately that seems highly unlikely.

[h1]One Piece: Pirate Warriors 4 is basically Pirate Warriors 3, but on crack. It takes what worked in that game, cranks it up to 11 and rolls with it.[/h1]

Graphically, the game is probably the best looking musou game on the market right now. It's colorful and vibrant, however the environment textures are still relatively low-rez. This, however, is made up by the fact that this game displays more enemies than any other musou before it; in some cases you can literally see hundreds of enemies at the same time, especially given the now more open level-design, another plus imo.

Musically, the game sounds good, with the addition of the anime soundtrack a bit nostalgic and perfectly fitting for this game.

The story follows the manga/anime, but it only covers a few, big arcs such as [spoiler] Enies Lobby [/spoiler], [spoiler] Impel Down [/spoiler] or the [spoiler] Whole Cake Island [/spoiler] arc. Everything else is covered in cutscenes featuring scenes from PW3, which somewhat feels lazy, but really isn't a problem. Of course, the main part of the game is it's post-game, which, just like in PW3, is amazing.

The gameplay is almost exactly the same as PW3, but with a few added mechanics to makes combos more fluent and thus more fun. Overall, it is incredibly satisfying and is now also customizable, giving every character the chance to equip any 4 moves you have unlocked, thus providing more variety. This, in turn, leads to the gamplay not becoming repetetive as quickly as other games in the genre.

Overall, if you liked PW3 and you want an enhanced version of it, this is it. If you've never played a Pirate Warriros game before or seen the anime, I recommend playing PW3 before this, to get an idea of the story and the gameplay basics. However, this game is amazing and I very much recommend it!

CONTENT

END

As far as One Piece Pirate Warriors installments go, this game is the A1-Steak Sauce Tier game of the century. DELICIOUS! I've played Pirate Warriors 3, and for some reason, Pirate Warriors 4 actually runs more smoothly on my computer, whereas Pirate Warriors 3 had a lot of bugs and often wouldn't play the cutscenes. I've also played through a lot of World Seeker, and this game is a lot more complete than World Seeker was. They got the original voice actors, everything is fleshed out, and this game is super complete from a music, voice and graphics standpoint (except for maybe some flat facial expressions). The combat system is pretty awesome, and the aerial combat system is an awesome addition to the game. If you are a One Piece fan, especially those who are huge fans like me, you'll be drawn into the game immediately. Other than the fact that they put a ton of emphasis on Marineford (as most games in the series do), the parts of the storyline they pick are awesome! The game doesn't really have any East Blue or Skypiea stages, but they do manage to touch a lot of the main plot in the first half of the game. 10/10 Would recommend to anyone who likes One Piece. If you've been following One Piece for the past 12 years like I have, the game will totally make your weekend awesome! :)

The best Pirate Warriors game of them all. This game shows that the devs learned a lot from PW3 and made sure to fix a lot of its problems.

The story flows nicely and it's not overfilled with unnecessary parts. My only complaint is that it doesn't have the Thriller Bark Arc but this one seems to focus more on the post-time-skip arcs, especially giving Whole Cake a whole lot of attention. Wano Arc is not the same as in the manga/anime, but that's fine because the game-exclusive Wano Arc was still very enjoyable to go through.

The character roster is quite large, adding up to 43 current characters, and of course the 9 upcoming DLC characters. Katakuri and the Vinsmoke brothers being unlockable through gameplay so you don't have to purchase the season pass yet. I would recommend waiting until they announce the DLC characters and then picking up whoever you like. However, personally, I got the season pass because I want to have all the characters regardless.

The combat is incredible. I've played many Musou games in my life, (including but not limited to: Dynasty Warriors 1 through 7, the previous Pirate Warriors games, and the Berserk Musou game), and I have to say this game is one of the best demonstrations of how fun and engaging the Musou battle system is. I feel a rush of adrenaline every time I finish a combo and topple a hundred enemies in one go.

On the completion side of things, this game is in the middle of the spectrum. There are only 3 main quest logs: The Dramatic Log which is the story mode where you play as a select set of characters each quest, the Free Log which allows you to replay Dramatic Log missions with any character you want, and the ratings you get for each quest is shared between the two logs, and finally, the Treasure Log, where you'll probably spend most of your time because it has a whole lot of quests that when completed will reward you with golden coins that you need to level up your characters skills or stats.

Speaking of which, the Growth Maps offer a decent method of progressing your characters through buffing their main stats or unlocking new abilities for them. You can choose up to 4 abilities for these characters to use during each battle but the number of abilities you can unlock makes it so you have options in case you wish to change up your play style whenever you want. The only thing that bothers me is that you have to select a mission first before you can access the Growth Map, which isn't much of a problem since you can still navigate between different characters' maps, it's just a tedious process is all. I'm hoping that in a future patch the devs will add a Growth Map option to the main menu just to make it easier to access.

Oh, right, I almost forgot. The graphics of the game are pretty good. They're not incredible or realistic to any measure, but they do the job of representing a CGI anime game. The action cutscenes are definitely incredible though. It feels like a trip down memory lane but also a whole new experience at the same time. 

All in all, I give this game a good ol' 9/10. It's incredibly fun and can get addicting if you're not careful. I mean, look at me, I played 12 hours of this on launch day alone. That's dangerous, but it's a damn good time. Anyway, that's all I got for you. If you read all that, thank you first of all, and I genuinely hope you give this game a try. As a One Piece and Musou game fan, this brings me so much joy. Can't wait for the DLC characters!

I've played the Dynasty Warriors titles from 1 to 5 with great pleasure until 6 disappointed. Picked up PW 3 last year and had tons of fun. This 4th part however blows it out of the water.

Pros:

- The gameplay is much smoother and the combos feel great. Aerial combat is just nuts.

- You can use and choose more special moves(musou). They all charge individually.

- The coin system seems less grindy so far.

- You have a lot more freedom on the maps. There're less invisible walls which gives a better feeling while traveling/fighting and you can destroy most buildings etc. Always wanted to use Whitebeards quake powers to destroy a bunch of buildings? Well here is your chance!

- Best thing of all is you can finally play the story via online coop, though it isn't perfect. You have to invite your friend for every map and don't stay together after finishing one.

Cons:

- The multiplayer might disconnect sometimes which they'll hopefully fix. It doesn't happen to often but still sucks since the person who disconnects doesn't get the points for that round.

- Some people seem to have lost their save file after the game crashed, though mine didn't crash once I wouldn't want that to happen. Needs to be fixed asap.

I bought this because Im a longtime one piece fan. If you are not a fan of the anime, this is just a mere mass mob hack n slash  game. If you are not a fan of hack n slash mob games, or a fan of one piece, you wont enjoy this game. I mildly enjoy dynasty warrior kind of games where Im an OP character that can wipe away hundreds of enemies with simple moves, but I bought it mostly because Im a longtime fan of OP. The combat is simple, but not mindless. You do have to figure out how to most efficiently dispatch enemies. The bosses do have unique movesets to them, and I find myself mixing up the special moves and combos for max effectiveness. Wouldnt call the combat "mindless", unless you put it on easy. 

The difficulty jump from normal to hard is pretty massive. You hardly ever have a chance to regen health on hard, but on medium they're everywhere. IF you are efficient enough with wiping away enemies. More enemies killed = more likely to pick up healing objects. If you kill a mini boss, they often drop full health restoring items. But on hard, they hardly ever drop anything. On normal I hardly struggle. On hard, I have to pay a lot more attention to my health. Problem is, I watch it go down when hardly anything is happening. Surrounded by hundreds of enemies at a time, cant really stare at every single one of them and determine whos damaging me and whos not while trying to wipe away hundreds of enemies efficiently.

Graphic wise, I havent had any issue with optimization. Game runs very smooth. No issues with cutscenes. But Ive read in the forums others have had issues with them. At first I had a problem with getting my controller to respond. I had to manually go into the games settings and enable controller input. 

Would I recommend this? depends. Do you like one piece? now, how do you feel about hack and slash mob games with bosses? If you're a fan like me and somewhat enjoy hack and slash, I would recommend the game. But not for $60... I would personally wait for a sale. I bought it for $60. Not going to refund it, but kinda wish I waited for a sale.

If you love hack and slash mob games and are a fan of one piece, I'd say yes, yes, yes, get it.

It's another musou game.

If you're into that genre, then this is a Good One, and you should check it out. If you're interested in One Piece, you should also check it out!

Honestly, this one plays a lot better than past entries in the series. They have really nailed the feeling of being in a sort of action shonen series fight. Boosting after enemies or to avoid attacks feels great, it's easy to use different special attacks and abilities, all the characters feel totally unique, it's just great all around. 

The RPG systems are interesting, you have like a whole bunch of skill trees to fill out. One for ALL characters, so new unlocks don't start out weak, and then multiple for each character. And they're not just giving 3% increased damage or whatever, they give whole new combat abilities and skills that really change the way the character plays. It's great.

I only have two quibbles with this game:
- It doesn't cover as much of the story of One Piece as the last one. But, this feels totally fair, as One Piece is an absolutely absurd amount of story to cover.
- They replaced the island-hopping mode from OPPW3 with just a list of maps to go through, which doesn't feel as fun, even though it's more convenient overall.

That's it! Otherwise, it's real good.

As for the game. the Pace is great. defeating huge armies of enemies is great. and seriously. i'm a big one-piece fan and this game sucked me in.
the soundtrack gets boring after a while BUT i didn't mind it because i was too focused on kicking akainu's a$$.

As mentioned before, i think the best point is the Pace and the musuo fights (as it should be... it's a musuo game...)
the Pace of the earlier arcs is fast and you reach marineford stage pretty fast.
I liked it because the previous games of the series covered it enough times already and this time it feels like you jump faster to the more recent content.
The cutscenes are nice and sometimes give you the feel of the anime but the game itself sometimes diverge from the anime itself and after a while returns to the original script.
Anyway. there is an option to skip it or disable it entirely.

lastly, i want to mention two last points about the game - the character progression and the tutorial.

The tutorial at the beggining is very fun and very satisfying (no spoilers), i'll just say i'm really hyped for reaching the end.
that's all i will say about it.

regarding the progression - it has way more choices than in previous games and it's satisfying to improve your character through it. you do some triall & error untill you get to the point you're satisfied with your main character's build.
all in all. i like the progression method used this time around.
