In short: Among the better games in the Warriors series.
+Beautiful art and animation. Nami truly is pleasing to the eye ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)
+Runs smoothly, minor choppiness during cutscenes
+++Combo system is really great and allows more options than any other game in the series I have played so far
+Destructible environment. Throwing enemies into buildings damages both enemies and the buildings, falling rubble causes damage to enemies. 
+Very fluid movement. Very few invisible walls (practically none)
+thousands of enemies to fight even in early maps, aside for 1v1 duels
+visits parts of the story not seen in previous games
--no remote play together support during the time of writing. Hoping for this to be fixed soon.
-certain maps do not allow coop at all, some allow only online coop for whatever reason.
-early on fighting some bosses feels dull, since you do so little damage to both their HP and shields. This does get fixed over time as your characters grow stronger.
-1v1 duels are generally dull because no hordes of peons flying around in the background
-some story points from older games are skipped altogether

Ok I’ve played for a little more than three hours so here are some of my honest first impressions of Pirate Warriors 4:

The combat is A LOT faster than PW3. It takes some getting used to in the beginning but once you get it it’s really satisfying. The combat animations are all really good and the different skills and classes for each character make them all feel unique. Lots of stage destruction and character voices. All your allies talk a lot during combat which makes the whole thing feel alive (For example Sanji names all his attacks which is really cool). Ariel combat is a nice touch too and extending combos into them is easy. I played on hard mode and I gotta say it’s far more challenging than PW3. If you’re up for the challenge I recommend it.

Like I said the combat is fast paced so that meant that the camera was super fast too. Imo the camera was way too sensitive but luckily there’s options to tone it down. The environments are very detailed and beautiful and the graphics in general are a huge improvement over the last game. Not to mention the roster is completely revamped and everyone has a different fresh moveset than before. The music is amazing as well.

Now for the negatives: 

The camera itself is not the best. When running from place to place it always forces you to slightly look downwards for some reason which is annoying at times but you get used to it. When you lock the camera onto a target, I’ll be frank, it’s not good. Due to the far field of view, when you get up close to your enemy, 80% of the time the camera won’t be focusing on them. The animations during dialogue scenes are not good. Sometimes the mouth movements don’t fit the tone or expressions of the characters at all. Also, the crew from what I’ve experience in the Alabasta arc are all stuck in there East Blue costumes. Although there are small iterations like the bandaged arms and Mr. Prince but it would’ve been far more appropriate to have their proper attires. Some cutscenes are also plainly copy pasted from the previous game. Though, the new rendered animations they made are really good.

These are my thoughts for now. I still think the gameplay is the core element of the game and I just love playing as One Piece characters in general so I’m still having a blast playing. If you’d ask me, I’d recommend it but that might just be my One Piece biased talking so I tried to be as honest as possible. Whether you decide to buy it or not is up to you but I hope you enjoy it if you do. 

PS: I don’t know if this mini review came off as more negative than positive but let me say that the positives are far more impactful than the negatives.

Onigiri Rice Balls

Learn to make one of Japanese cuisine's favourite snack foods with this onigiri recipe. Onigiri are balls of rice, usually wrapped with nori seaweed and containing a meat or vegetable filling. Much like sandwiches in the West, onigiri are readily available in convenience stores across Japan and are great for a quick and easy snack. Aesthetically pleasing and really tasty, they are a fun and filling alternative to sandwiches for lunch. Shop our delicious range of white rice perfect for making onigiri. 

Ingredients
per onigiri rice ball:
65g cooked japanese rice
1/4 sheet nori seaweed
pinch of salt
shiso perilla leaf (optional)
sesame seeds (optional)

possible fillings:
cooked chicken
cooked salmon
tuna mayo
pickled plums
tsukemono japanese pickles

For those looking to see if the game works or if it's a good port or just wanting to know what's different about this title, I'll be giving a quick review of features and functionality, not so much content.

I'm reading a lot of other reviews talk about controllers not working, but I've not had any of this. I use a PS4 controller, no extra software installed. Worked up front with no additional issues. I cannot vouch for others, but this is my experience.

While the game comes with a lot of graphical options for fine-tuning your experience, it looks as you'd expect. Graphics are not spectacular, but they are what they are. Even pushed to max, it's not a visually impressive game.

As far as I can personally speak, the game runs very smoothly (60fps) with no hitches or anything as long as you hardware can push that. I can't imagine you'd need much, but it seems to be one of the better Warriors ports that we've seen. There are more options in the menus than I've ever seen before, so it seems they've finally modernized a little bit.

Now, when it comes to gameplay, there are some very big changes for Musou fans. Firstly, the game still plays like you'd expect. Normal attacks mixed with Charge attacks to make unique combos. There are MANY more combos in this game than before, and now jumping in the middle of a combo will launch enemies into the air so you can continue fighting in the air. Because of this, there seems to be a lot more input options and ways to chain combos together. [b]Musou attacks have been removed entirely.[/b] Instead, there is now a skill palette system. You hold down RB/R1 to pull up 4 skills on the face buttons and you can use those whenever they are charged. They charge up by damaging enemies. Every character has their own skill tree that can unlock new combos and new skills that you can then slot into your character's skill palette. You can only have 4 active skills equipped at a time, so there are more skills than you'll need, offering for a lot of variation in what you can do between players. Each character also has an archetype now. Depending on that, your boost mode (called Full Force Burst) will provide different bonuses, such as faster traversal on the map or increased damage. Overall, it adds an attack speed boost to all characters. Each character has a skill tree, as I mentioned before, and there you can also find passive upgrades to damage, defense, stamina, and life. There's also one big skill tree that affects ALL characters, so you can choose to level up everyone or focus on a few. These trees are separate, so you can do both.

These are all of the major changes I've encountered in the first two hours of play; I'm sure there are more. As you can imagine, the game does feel a little different from the typical Warriors experience (to me, anyway). It feels more like a brawler with a few Musou elements. I'm a little sad Musou attacks are gone, but the overall combat does feel a little bit more varied and deeper now because of the changes. It's also possible that greater attacks will be unlocked later that can make up for that lack of "musou attack" gravitas.

So far, it's a recommend for One Piece fans, though it's probably not enough to bring in outside fans not already familiar, as the story also picks up in the middle of the One Piece story, so there's very little build up or background for any of the characters. Playing Pirate Warriors 3 before this one would be a better introduction to the game, and PW3 is also much more similar to the Dynasty Warriors formula.
